title: Gripping and intriguing
review:
The Plot In the sequel to the excellent 2004 film, Jigsaw locks a few unlucky people in a house filled with booby traps and they must find a way out before they inhale too much of a lethal nerve gas and die. But they must watch out, for if they don't figure out what each of them have in common, the traps Jigsaw has set in the shelter will lead to gruesome deaths.

The film also centers around a cop who is trying everything in his power to save his son who is in the house with all the other people.

The Pros The story is very clever, much like the first one which was better. The gore and the blood is awesome and the acting is surprisingly good too. The booby traps are the best, as you watch these poor innocent people battle to save their lives by getting out of the brilliantly built traps. Don't think this is a lame horror film because it actually isn't. It is really worth watching.

The Cons Some people may not be able to handle the blood and gore and might just be put off, but that's their problem. They would be missing out on a really great story.

Worth hiring/buying? It is definitely worth hiring. Buy only if you're a horror movie collector.

The Final Word A non-stop gore fest with intelligent writing and directing. This film will appeal to all avid horror fans,

title: Just as good as the 1st...
review:
Like the title states, this film was both gory and psychologically terrifying which seems to be a rare situation for the horror/thriller genre nowadays. I saw it the 1st day it came out knowing it would be a very smart thriller. and I am pleased to say that this movie has been added to my short list of "Sequels Better or Just As Good As the Original".

This movie will have you on the edge of your seat from beginning to end. It will leave you haunted for at least the rest of the night with a heightened fear of being in enclosed areas.

I knew there was going to be a big twist at the end but I couldn't foresee what it was going to be...be prepared to be surprised.It has no holes and is perfectly put together and Saw is just acted out perfect.

I recommend this to anyone who is up for a smart thriller.

title: A Sequel to Challenge the Original
review:
"Violent. Gory. Pointless. Needless. Entertaining. Thoughtles." It's very easy to right off the Saw series if you haven't actually seen it yourself. The way that it is portrayed and talked about by some people just makes it seem like a needless bloodbath of imaginative deaths, occasionally flavoured with some headache inducing twists and turns that bring up more questions rather than answering the ones that have already come up. Sure enough, the latter is often frustrating and seems to have become a popular trend. It's either a sign that the writer's don't know what they are doing or that they have a far bigger picture in mind. The fact that there will be at least 5 saw films perhaps points to the second option.

Saw II is quite different from the original. This is perhaps inevitable since it not only was made by someone else, but wasn't even a Saw sequel originally. Therefore it's easy to think that it might become a Blair Witch 2 type tack-on-easy-money-farce that it could well be. The Saw films are very clever, and this is often brought up by those who appreciate it. However the violence gets more publicity, and the simple truth is that it arouses enough curiosity to convince people to go and see it. The original Saw wasn't actually that violent. Much like Se7en, a film it is compared to but frankly isn't in the same class as, most of the nasty events are left to the imagination of the audience. Even the most famous scene, where Cary Elwes saws off his own foot, you see absolutely nothing. Saw II changes it's style, and is hard to stomach on occasion. However, the film gets it's nastiest death out of the way straight away. A protagonist who seems to be a snitch and a voyeur, much like Adam from the original, has what is described as a Venus fly trap round his head. It will slam shut, crushing his head, if he doesn't unlock it with a key before a minute runs out. The key happens to be behind his eye. Although he never goes as far as to get the key, the idea in itself is disturbing. After this the deaths aren't particularly gratuitous. In fact the scenario, solve puzzles to find a cure for a nerve gas destroying your system, is more horrifying then the way in which most of the people die.

The plot itself is simple and well defined, and newcomer Bousman makes sure that the film doesn't go off the rails and lose it's focus. Donnie Wahlberg, in excellent, and as usual, understated form, plays Detective Eric Matthews, the principle main character. His son has been kidnapped by the infamous 'Jigsaw' killer, and he, along with a number of unfortunate souls who have an unseen connection, are locked up in an old house. The only hope that Matthews has of saving his son is by finding out from the old and dying Jigsaw where he is. There are the two main stories that overlap each other, of Matthews and his team at Jigsaw's workshop, and his son and the other victims in the house. The formula allows an opportunity for the characters to grow themselves, and one of the understated values of the film is the characterisation. Matthews at first simply seems burnt out after a tough career, but it soon becomes clear that he is far from the perfect cop. The man on the floor (or house, as it were) who seems to take control and act as a leader, Xavier, is in fact a selfish and overbearing drug dealer who cares about no one but himself. It would be easy for the makers to drop good characterisation and get down to the bloodletting, as many feel is the case with Saw III. It is a credit to Bousman that he appreciates the most important aspects of making a great film: plot, characters, dialogue, atmosphere. By keeping these as a priority, and it makes the film easier to appreciate and makes it seem less like a popcorn movie.

Another important factor in making a good film is usually down to the actors themselves. Whereas this could have B-Movie performances, all the displays are solid and excellent. The fear, frustration and anger flows in a way that really surprises you. From the genuine terror and panic of the opening scene's character to the deep emotion of Matthews, the characters are believable and aren't just cardboard cutouts. Singling out Wahlberg as the star performer may be harsh on a quality cast, but the fact is that he has the hardest character to portray and pulls it off with flying colours. It's miles away from his performance as another cop, the earnest and honest detective Joel Stevens in Boomtown. Ultimately though, the film works so well because all the elements come together and create a film that isn't just entertaining but is also believable and terrifying.

Inevitably, most people probably think that the Saw series is pure popcorn and gore, and in many ways it is. Indeed the premise is sick at best. But in Saw II you have a film that shouldn't be THAT good but is, and it more than matches the original for atmosphere and drama. It's well worth it watching not just for the entertainment, but also for the great way in which it has been made. That is, of course, if you can stomach the violence.

title: Those who do not appreciate life do not deserve life
review:
Directed by Darren Lynn Bousman and stars Donnie Wahlberg as tough Detective Eric Matthews, Tobin Bell as brilliant psychopath Jigsaw aka John Kramer and Shawnee Smith as Amanda Young. This sequel to the first smash hit Saw is about a group of people held captive inside a house full of traps especially made for them by Jigsaw. While Jigsaw is being held by the police, Det Eric Matthews tries to squeeze out information from Jigsaw as to where the house might be. It turns out that the house is filled with lethal nerve gas that kills the people inside (unfortunately, Det Eric Matthews' son, Daniel is also inside) within two hours. A door will open after three hours so that means that they can't live that long when the door opens. So, Jigsaw has scattered antidotes all over the house so they can live and escape the house. With the clock ticking, Det Eric Matthews must save his son and the people inside before its too late.

Great twisted plot and a twisted ending makes this film stand out from the rest. Great acting by Tobin Bell as Jigsaw and Donnie Wahlberg. This films keeps you hanging in a balance and it keeps you guessing till the end. Also, Adam's carcass gives a special participation and so is Zep's rotting body and Dr. Gordon's foot. And yes, the infamous bathroom from Saw will be featured in Saw II. 8/10

title: Worthy Sequel.
review:
"Saw II" begins with another poor victim of the relentless Jigsaw serial killer (Tobin Bell), who is part of another "death trap" that will squash his head like a pumpkin unless he can remove the key - from behind his eyeball. Need I say more? We then are introduced to a group of more victims placed in one of Jigsaw's horrible traps. They each awake in an old, rundown house in a sealed off room. Disoriented and confused, the helpless people don't know what to do. Then, they find a tape player that explains the deadly nerve gas they are slowly breathing in, and how they must find the antidotes that can save them. Among them is a previous victim, Amanda (Shawnee Smith), who is familiar with Jigsaw's games. It then becomes a constant battle of life or death as the unlucky people begin to turn on each other.

I have to admit, this was a pretty good film for being a horror sequel. In most cases, sequels don't even come close to meeting the expectations set from the original movie, but "Saw II" comes really close to it. The thing I liked most about this film was how there were more characters to interact with each other - there wasn't a whole lot of character development per se, but it was interesting how all of them interact and ultimately turn on each other. Just goes to show how much will some people have to save themselves, and how selfish some people are. I really liked that aspect of it.

The acting wasn't bad at all, I thought everyone involved did a pretty good job, so I really have no complaints there. Good performance from Donnie Wahlberg as a cop, and Shawnee Smith as a returning victim (?) of Jigsaw. The script was clever and the ending was a little bit of a shock for me, and the film ended on a note quite similar to the original. There's plenty of violence and elaborate traps for the ill-fated characters (even more elaborate and grotesque than what the original film had featured), so gore hounds should really enjoy this stuff.

Overall, "Saw II" is a worthy sequel that comes close to meeting the standards that the first film set. It was clever (as expected), suspenseful, and cringe-inducing, as this series should be. Fans couldn't have asked for a better sequel. Not bad, not bad at all. 8/10.

title: Excellent sequel
review: For the true horror fan who loves to cringe at ones worst fears this movie is for you. I've seen so many horrible horror movies, many of them homages to older horror movies. Saw broke the mold and Saw II has only carried on its legacy. Amazing opening scene, that kicks the movie into overdrive from the beginning. All the death scenes are so visceral, which makes it that much better. My favorite scene, which also freaks the hell out of me is the pit of needles, it makes me uneasy just thinking about. The only thing I didn't like about the movie was the psycho in the house, he seemed a bit over the top to me. In the end though I felt satisfied Saw II and thirsty for Saw III.

title: The Twist no one SAW coming
review:
After being able to see Part I the sequel was a must see. Of course as skeptical as I can be never really thought a sequel can be this good. The movie no change from the first of course is a bloody foul language film that under 17 is a must to watch flick, but no nudity to what I recall. Of course Jigsaw is still trying to play the playful life tester that is only getting worse by the minute. I recommend this film to the horror loving audience now if the sight of blood the feeling of nauseous arises I suggest to think twice about the film. There is action, suspense, twist and of course thrill that makes Saw II one of the best in my opinion.

title: Better or worse?
review:
After seeing Saw, i was reluctant to see the second saw, only because i was afraid that it wouldn't live up to its amazing prequel. after seeing it, I wasn't sure if it was better than the original or worse.

the things that i loved from the original were the plot line, the twist at the end, the overall scaryness, and the fact that it seemed to pull you into that disgusting room. i also loved some of adam's lines. however, I didn't like the fact that it jumped "storylines", like switching from the family to the bathroom, and just a thought: how did he take the picture of his family then put it into his wallet, if he was already captive? jw

anyway, with the second one. great plot line, great twist, great acting, great emotion, but it also didn't seem so real, and some of the lines were overdone, and the ending lines were already done (game over, leaving someone in the room in the darkness).

so that leaves the question: which one is better?

i still love this movie though, and will definitely watch it again.

title: The Return of JIGSAW
review:
Yes, that is correct, Jigsaw has returned for a second round with more victims to torture. His demented games have gotten worse and his victims, stranger. In fact, if you haven't noticed, the victims all seem to know one another.

This time, Jigsaw is caught by the police. And while the clock runs down, they must find this set of victims before it is too late. One of the victims just happens to be the son of the police officer who is questioning Jigsaw. Coincidence? Think again. Jigsaw plans all of his "games" in advance. He seems to know very well what will happen next.

The viewer will be surprised by the ending of the film. It is a twist that not even the best movie critic could have thought of. The film is ingenious. Therefore, like the first, "Saw II" gets 10 out of 10.

title: "Saw II" horror feature ups the ante second time around
review:
It's truly amazing what the right amount of hype and the right kind of audience can do for a movie; "Saw II" embraces its following so that genre veterans can be full-on prepared for another grisly gore-fest designed to test the human will to simply survive. This time, the Jigsaw killer (Tobin Bell), is out in the open, and does not speak to us through a gruesome-looking puppet or a tape recording.

As we remember from "Saw" (2004), Jigsaw is technically not a serial killer, at least in the traditional sense; he often sets up elaborate methods for his victims to kill themselves (i.e., a man rubbed down in flammable chemicals must find the combination to a safe etched in a wall before the candle he's holding ignites him, or another victim must crawl through a yard of barb wire to an exit before a timer runs out and the door slams shut).

This time, Jigsaw sets up a funhouse for eight unknown people (including Shawnee Smith as "Saw" survivor Amanda, back for round two) who are all somehow connected, and it's up to dogged cop Eric Matthews (Donnie Wahlberg) to figure out where they are and save them. As for the poor souls in the booby-trapped house, they have three hours to locate the exit, or antidote, before they are all nerve-gassed to death. They're all the typical undesirables who have to prove their worth if they are to survive by playing Jigsaw's twisted game. Matthews takes it personal because his son is one of Jigsaw's latest victims in the house.

In the director's seat this time is newcomer Darren Lynn Bousman, who shares a screenplay credit with original "Saw" screenwriter Leigh Whannell, who played one of Jigsaw's victims in the first film. "Saw II" is at least clever enough to roughly follow the same pattern as its predecessor, but is even more clever to at least build on those ideas and not repeat itself. Whannell and Bousman's script still has that rare distinction of being simultaneously brilliant and god-awful and the players are still unlikeable, but Bousman is able to keep enough of a firm grip on the material that it never slips into mediocrity or stupidity.

The nightmarish, funhouse tricks & traps scenario is something straight out of an S & M fantasy, highlighted greatly by tripped-out editor Kevin Greutert and David Hackl's twisted, goth-inspired production design. I'm sure that for this casual horror fan, "Saw II" has still provided sufficient, delightful pre-Halloween entertainment, just as "Saw" did two years ago. I would guess that "Saw III" can only bring about a thoughtful conclusion, if that is indeed what Jigsaw has in store for us later this week.

8/10

title: Twists and turns - expect the unexpected!
review:
I can't make a decent review of the movie, so I'll just share some of my thoughts on it. Here goes nothing: First of all, this was NOT a ripoff of CUBE. True enough, both movies involve a theme of strangers being trapped in a mystery house full of traps and dangers; however, the similarities end there. Okay? Now shut up about it, if that's what has been holding you back from seeing it.

By far and wide, there were definitely some scenes in this movie which were hard to watch, but they worked in the aspect of the movie. It's a perfect example of gore being used to further the horror of a situation, rather than exploiting it for that purpose. Needless (now I shudder at how similar that word is to another one...) to say, this movie was less a splatter film and more of a psychological mystery - JUST like the original SAW.

One slight problem I had with the movie was a fault entirely of my own. For quite some time now, I knew something about how this movie was going to end. No-no, don't worry, I'm not going to give anything away; but basically I'll use this analogy: Let's say someone in 1983 who never saw the original two STAR WARS movies hears about RETURN OF THE JEDI coming, and that there's something about Han Solo having to get rescued. They get curious, and they watch the first movie. Then, shortly before RETURN comes out, they see EMPIRE, but already they know that Han Solo gets into some kind of trouble. Carbonite, et al, happens, and it's just not as effective, but it was still a good movie.

That's what my situation was with the SAW movies; I watched the first one, loved it, and as I waited and waited for II to come out on DVD in its uncut edition (I'm a dork, I know), I keep hearing things about the third movie which began to make me think. I prettymuch had the end to SAW II figured out for a while, and the whole time I was watching it, I was hoping to be corrected. Unfortunately, I was right...but you see, there are TWO twists to this movie, which both happen back-to-back and within one another. I wasn't sure what the *other* twist was, at first, but reading some of the spoiler-heavy posts on the message board after watching the movie, I suddenly got slapped in the face with that other twist...and needless to say, I spent a good few minutes laughing at the shock of it. So, I got my awesome twist ending after all...even if I knew one aspect of it already.

I did give this movie a 9 out of 10 star rating, and that was because of a few problems I had with it. One of them was my above "spoiled foreshadowing," but that hardly is a reason to dislike the movie. My problems were mostly in a couple of the characters. Here you have such complicated and profound characters like Jigsaw, and this movie does a really good job at exploring them; and then there's Xavier and Detective Eric Matthews. Some of the decisions they make in the movie work only to further the plot, and are either very unprecedented or disagreeable. Something Xavier does at one point is so left-field and horrendous, and it really bugs me that he did it; but then again, it helped the plot along, and I guess that makes up for it. On a further note about him, I liked Franky G in THE Italian JOB, and I thought he was a very talented actor there; seeing him in this role made me feel like it was a bit of a waste for him. Oh well, he's getting more famous now, anyway.

Oh, speaking of actors, I really enjoyed Shawnee Smith. She was basically the star of the movie, to me; her character of Amanda, from her reaction to waking up in the house and screaming her horror, to...other, later points (gah, I swear that pun was unintended!), was executed with real conviction and talent. I, for one, am a fan of this actress now. And Tobin Bell...he has set the high bar on what a villain is like, and I, for one, thought he did splendidly as the awesomely complicated Jigsaw.

So in retrospect, this movie was full of thrills, twists, and tons of scares. It was every bit as good as the original, and even a bit better at times. All in all, SAW II was a perfect example of a psychological horror movie done right, and an excellent follow-up to its groundbreaking predecessor.

A-

title: Great Movie
review:
Watching this movie kept me on the edge of my seat the entire time. As you watch it you cant help but try to examine every detail trying to find out the ending before it happens. The Twist and turns that the stories plot takes you on will lead you as far away form the right guess as possible but in the end give you all the info you can handle. This movie definitely surpasses the first Saw in terms of over all gore and blood. Also in terms of making you think and getting into your head it is way better. To think that someone could even think of these things for a movie is hard to think about. All I know is that it made for a great movie.

I felt i had to watch this movie with the new Saw 3 coming out and it definitely lived up to what I had been hearing. Can't wait to see the new movie coming out soon. And Hope that this series of movies keeps going on for a few more.

title: I saw "saw2"
review:
"Saw 2 " is almost as gripping as the first film,in several respects ,it even surpasses it.It's not for everyone,for it is often unbearable.But the two movies completely renewed the horror movie,without using too many special effects which marred so many gore movies of the two previous decades.

This must be the screenplays .They are well-constructed stories,and the characters are not the usual cardboard persons we find in the likes of "Friday the thirteen" or "Freddy".This sequel expertly combines Agatha Christie's "And then there were none" aka "ten little Indians"(all the prisoners in the house have done something wrong),Greek myths (the myth of the labyrinth and the Minotaur is obvious), metaphysical concerns (why do people fight for their dear life only when they are in jeopardy?Why must I die when the others are to carry on their earthly ride?),and games of logic ("you will never be able to read your own number"),bringing all back home.As if it were not enough,the final expected twist leaves the audience panting for breath....and eagerly waiting for "saw 3".

title: Worthy sequel that narrowly falls short of its predecessor
review:
Exasperated with people taking life for granted, the cancer riddled sadistic killer, Jigsaw, is back for a second bout of intricately engineered games of death, designed to make his victims prove they are worthy of existence.

Saw, released in 2004, achieved cult status through its innovative approach to the horror/serial killer genre. A cleverly worked script with twists and turns overcame some dodgy acting and turned Saw into a triumph. The inevitable sequel builds on the premise of the first by introducing ever more elaborate schemes for the victims to die, in Jigsaws twisted little games. Half the fun is trying to figure out how the next trap can possibly outdo the previous one in terms of violence and 'look through your fingers in disgust'. Yet each time the deaths get ever more depraved.

The tag line says it all. If you can't handle the blood then stay the hell away. This is not one for the faint hearted. I deny anyone to watch this film without feeling tense and uneasy. It's chilling atmosphere sends a wave of foreboding and fear flooding through your veins as you expect something horrible round every corner. In terms of pure fright Saw actually fails to deliver many jumps and jolts, purely because you are generally expecting the worst. But in terms of sustained grimace and horror for what the characters are going through, Saw lets your blood boil, forgetting about the off switch.

Unfortunately Saw is let down by some painfully poor acting which seems to have been unceremoniously accredited to the horror genre. Part of the reason the original was so highly regarded was the gritty interaction of its two main characters working with and against each other in their desperate situation. With a larger cast its successor loses all notions of character development and portrays a group of impossibly dumb individuals and, therefore, a very unbelievable bunch of idiots.

Although it loses the original impact of its predecessor, Saw II is a commendable but significantly weaker sequel. It still manages to blow the majority of modern horror films out of the water, delivering some of the most memorable and haunting sequences of recent memory. However, it isn't a patch on 'The Decent' when it comes to the terror department.

title: Oh yes...there was blood
review: (insert evil clown laugh) Again going for a Halloween release like it's first film, Saw 2 had what i call classic scenes. The opening scene where the poor guy has to cut out his eye to get the key behind it to unlock his death mask in less than 60 seconds was definitely frightening. Scary Movie 4 found good jokes in parody-ing that part. The needle pit, the hand trap, the furnace were all fine and dandy, but i found interesting was the exploring of John's(Jigsaw) life. He actually liked him in this movie as i got to know him. Again this movie featured a surprise ending no one sees coming once again. Then there was the scene towards the end that was hard to watch when the muscle man has to cut off the back of his neck to get one of the numbers of the combination to the safe which holds the antidote to the poison that has been slowly killing him. If you liked the first movie you'll like this one and your fan-ism will grow more.

title: Worth watching, though lacks the intensity of the first
review:
Saw II is certainly worth a couple of hours of your life, but you will come away with a sense of "been there, done that. bought the t shirt already." Yes it has a couple of novel new and horrid ways of killing/ torturing people but all in all it is a retread, and not necessarily of the first Saw film alone. The group dynamic, in needing to solve puzzles to escape with their lives, is very reminiscent of Cube, a much tighter thriller in my opinion, perhaps only because it never cuts away from the central action- there is no let up.

The vast majority of the characters in the house remain cardboard cut outs- we don't really see beyond their criminal activities. So we have "the ex junkie" "the drug dealer" "the prostitute" but you'll be surprised if you remember their names, or anything else that made them distinctive. Perhaps this is deliberate- you get the various guilty pleasure of watching them die in numerous ways without really caring for them as people, but in reality it removes a sense of intensity and tension which I found in the first Saw movie. We actually care about the doctor in that film.

The character of Jigsaw/ John is demystified here also as we get to see too much of him. He lacks the presence of, say, Anthony Hopkin's Hannibal Lecter so it feels as if the more we see of him the less impact he has, the less fearsome he appears, though at the same time it isn't as if these feelings are replaced with sympathy or pity. He's just there.

I won't say too much about the twist (well twists I guess) at the end, other than they felt silly, whereas I remember my stomach lurching when the final twist in the original film was released. I'm a bit concerned about Saw 3 and the direction one of the twists implies it will take the series. I'm not sure if I can take it as seriously- it feels more like a vehicle for extending the longevity of the film series, rather than something that is important in terms of plot. Time will tell I guess!

To summarise, it is worth a rent, perhaps a blind purchase if you're a big fan of the first or a completist. It certainly isn't an atrocious sequel, but it does feel a little paint-by-numbers detective/serial killer/ horror at times. It's a fun way to pass a couple of hours though, and I certainly didn't find myself bored, though perhaps a little less involved than in the first film.

title: it's a different movie, but....not bad at all
review:
i rented this movie (missed it in the theater unfortunately) with high hopes, having really liked the first one. And i wasn't disappointed, although Saw 2 is an entire different movie than the original.

The first major difference is: we now know the killer, which initially is a bit of a let down because the search for the identity of "jigsaw" was what made the first one so great. But from the moment detective Matthews finds Jigsaw and we discover that his Son is in Jigsaw's house of "fun", The movie became really interesting. Jigsaw's proposition to Det.Matthews to just sit there and talk, seemed strange but made you wanna watch the movie a bit more to see where all this was gonna lead to.

The second difference is: except for the (really strong and awfully gory) opening sequence the victims aren't individually trapped, but are all together in a big booby trapped house, from which they have to find a way out. Although it reminded me a bit of the movie "Cube", i found this to be a fresh new perspective of the killers games. it seems like the victims have a choice, while in fact everything that Jigsaw has planned for them, actually happens (ofcourse in the climax of the movie is revealed who of the "victims" we have to thank for that) The third difference is that this time, the movie IS very gory. While the first movie wasn't all that explicit as far as the violence is concerned, the second one shows all the nasty things in all it's glory.

The acting, again, isn't top notch (Although Tobin Bell and Donnie Wallberg do an excellent job) but this time the victims are so annoying that you could't care less what's gonna happen to them. As far as i'm concerned this made the movie a little bit less exciting to watch. But the ending, although not as brilliant as the original, again really amazed me and lifted the movie far above average as far as i'm concerned. If you liked the first one, you really won't be disappointed by Saw 2. If you didn't like the first one, but you are a Horror fan, still give this one a chance, you might like it

title: Not as fabulous as the first one
review:
A group of strangers get trapped together in a room and have to find a way out before they get killed by the gas Jigsaw has filled the room with.

First of all I want to say that I had high expectations for this movie since I loved Saw so much. I saw the sequel last night, and I had mixed feelings about it after seeing it. I still think that the first Saw is better because of its magic and the performance of Johns' voice. The second movie I kind of knew what was going to happen, cause John wants to kill these person of the same reason as the first Saw. He wants them to find out how much they appreciate their lives. I felt like there was something missing when I was watching the sequel. It didn't have the same magic effect of suspense and shock as the first one. And Jigsaw was suddenly not so scary anymore. Just a poor guy in a chair, waiting to die. In the first movie he was so brutal, clever and many twists and turns with a brilliant ending I loved so much -- but all of that was like gone when I saw the sequel. I guess I got kind of disappointed. It just didn't have the same 'charm' but the conversation between Jigsaw and Matthews were unforgettable.

review:

title: Hits a nerve- just like the first one!
review:
I'm what you could call a horror film fan myself, yet very few films scare or shock me anymore. I remember when i watched the first "Saw" I was so impressed because the film hit a deep nerve, it did what no "horror" film had managed to do for a long time. Well i have to say, i was even more impressed with Saw 2- there were moments in the film where i actually gasped allowed, and the narrative twists and turns kept coming. And once again the ending leaves the viewer with an eerie sense of dread. The character of Jigsaw himself is masterfully created, to the point where you almost want to say you agree with what hes saying, or you can see his point of view.

I must say that the general standard of acting in this film, is much better than the original. Hopefully the director will move onto other things, possibly in the same vein as Saw, psychological horror is doing well right now and id love to see him try something in this genre again.

title: A Worthy Sequel
review: This is a worthy sequel, although it doesn't measure up to the first one, its still better than 90% of films in this genre. The direction is pretty good, and the acting is also pretty good. It was actually funnier than the first one, which i don't know is a good thing or not because its not a comedy. The only thing that made it not measure up to the original was the fact that i could see the twist coming and could actually kinda tell where the film was heading. I thought it was very entertaining and well acted and directed though. Donnie Wahlberg and Shawnee Smith were good but the standout was Tobin Bell who played an amazing villain. 9/10

title: Interesting, if overblown
review:
Saw 2 is an OK movie thats a little over the top. The opening scene was hard for me to watch as it had do with eye gouging, which is the one type of gore i can't take. Anyway, it involves 8 people trapped in a house, including the son of a detective that has just busted jigsaw. Jigsaw is not only playing a game with the people in the house, but also with the detective. As the story progresses you learn more and more about the people and why their there. It does keep you hooked and i would have rated this movie higher had it not been for the ending. SPOILER AHEAD,

As it turns out, Ammanda is Jigsaw protégé, which sets it up for saw 10000 or however many their gonna make of these, end up ruining the series of course. The ending kinda ruined it for me, had they had a better ending i would have rated it an 8.

title: Reasonable but not as good as the original.
review:
It seems like such a cliché to say it but I have to go along with the majority of other reviewers who seem to be agreed that 'Saw II' is basically not as good as the original. That still leaves a lot of scope however, given that 'Saw' was such an excellent film.

It may just be that sequels never work (Godfather Part II being the exception that proves the rule!) But it is always disappointing when you have enjoyed the first one so much, to finish watching the second with a feeling of letdown.

That said, Saw II is not in itself a bad film. It only really suffers in comparison to its predecessor. The pace of the sequel is good, the original premise is retained but with interesting new twists and the acting is, in general, better than average - without any one performance worthy of being singled out as excellent (with the possible exception of Tobin Bell's menacing portrayal of Jigsaw).

One of the main problems here is that the script is crammed full of too many characters, and so there is little time for developing these and giving them real depth, with the result that a few of them are really fairly one-dimensional, about whom it is difficult to care too much. (This is a mistake that was very much NOT the case with the original!)

Overall, it's OK. Go and see it. But just don't expect anything miraculous - and I'd certainly say that you should not see this film without seeing the original Saw first.

title: Well worth a watch
review: Saw 2 is that rare thing. A sequel that is better than the original. That's my opinion anyway. If you are a fan of horror movies this is one you want to see. It is unpredictable with many twists and turns which will have you glued to the screen. It has all that was contained in Saw 1 and the action is similar. One drawback I had with the film was that I found it particularly gory. Some parts I just could not watch.( I hate seeing cruelty). If you liked Saw 1 you will love this. It is a film for all horror fanatics and I think that the story line is very good. This film could be enjoyed without seeing the first but I advise seeing the first to enhance your enjoyment of this film.

title: Decent follow up
review:
Gory as hell and proud of it, Saw seemingly came out of nowhere to grab cinema goers by the throat, shake them violently and vomit blood into their faces. Thanks to it's success a sequel was inevitable but when it followed the original in less than a year and still turned out to be a decent follow up that in places surpasses it's older brother was about as expected as the Spanish inquisition. And as the tagline boasts the level of depravity reaches all new levels.

Setting the tone instantly, the first five minutes sees Jigsaw's latest victim having to make the decision between having his head splattered in a giant metal trap or carve his own eye out in order to retrieve the key to open it. True to the hype's promises the claret is gushing in seconds and when the cops arrive to investigate this rather unpleasant demise, the story properly kicks into gear. Bursting into a warehouse, the police led by detective Eric Matthews (Donnie "New Kid On the Block" Wahlberg) corner Jigsaw in his den and all seems to be neatly wrapped up. Before you can say "Gee, that was a very brief and concise short film" however the villain plays his ace in the hole; he has eight people locked up in a house riddled with traps who are slowly dying from breathing in air tinged with a tissue destroying virus and one of them is Matthew's delinquent teenage son.

What follows plays out in two separate strands - Jigsaw plays his game of cat and mouse with the police while the eight victims of his scheme try to escape the house and meet all sorts of nasty ends along the way. Revealing too much more would give away too many of the twists and turns the plot takes along the way, but rest assured fans of the original will find plenty to relish in here. Spiked baseball bats, bladed hand traps, booby-trapped ovens and a pit filled with thousands upon thousands of used needles ramp the level of unpleasantness right up and there are none of the irritating flashbacks to disrupts proceedings like in the first film.

It's not perfect of course. Grim and depraved it may be but 'Seven' it most certainly isn't and once again, every little twist has to be painstakingly explained but as far as squirm-in-your-seat film making goes, it's certainly effective. Jigsaw himself also has a far more active role this time round and makes a decidedly menacing presence but it is the link to the prequel that really seals the deal, a final act revelation so delightfully messed up it'll be with you for days.

title: Saw 2
review:
Saw 2 is not your average horror film. Like its predecessor, you will not see teenagers having rampant sex and you won't be screaming at the screen "Don't go there, moron!" Saw 2, however, is also not all that scary in and of itself. It is a gory movie, which might scare some people, but where the fear comes into play with the Saw movies is that they are, ultimately, plausible. Unline many horror movies.

"Jigsaw" is back. The first scene of the movie is, in my opinion, more gory than the entirety of Saw. This time, Jigsaw gets caught early on in the movie, but that was his whole plan in the first place. The story that unravels is filled with twists and half truths, and what befalls a certain detective could have been averted by simply listening.

The ending is a bit obvious, but the plot is excellent.

title: Equals its predecessor, more than most sequels achieve...
review:
I WILL give this film full marks, simply because I think it is one of the few horror/thriller films that actually shows originality and flair, and has a twist that you actually DON'T guess until pretty much the end of the movie.

I think that Saw was could be defined as the better of the two, although obviously that's only because its the first. But sequels are far too often made-for-profit to the extent where they lose sight of trying to provide adequate value for money - the Saw franchise does (see my review of Final Destination 3 to see one that doesn't).

I like that it shows continuity from the first film, neatly tying in the cliffhanger ending without ripping off what made the first one successful, and even though you may guess the twist a little more easily second time around, it is no less exciting. I definitely recommend this film for those people who hate spending money on movies they 'know' they won't enjoy. If you like horror, suspense, mystery and an all round mental challenge when viewing movies, then Saw I and II are the ones for you. Looking forward to the Saw III!

title: A 15 year old opinion on SAW
review:
I highly seeing Saw II with a buddy who can make you laugh because after this you will want to laugh. If you're like me who gets reacquainted with popcorn during your scary movie visit get the big bucket and turn to blame your friend for taking you to see it. If you are in the comfort of your own home, have friends and you re watch it the next morning or watch Making Of featurette.

I also think you should see Saw the first one so you know what is happening or where Amanda is coming from. Also go see Saw III.

Sadly somehow I think we can all learn a lesson from these movies...value your life!!

title: Gore with a twist
review: Does anyone remember TV coverage of the US elections when crowds chanted "WE WANT GORE WE WANT GORE" well, here it is in all its teeth clenching glory - the opening scene is a real eye-full! Anyway, if you get past the grimace making realistic mutilation (excellent effects and make-up by the way) there's a neat twisty turny double helix of a plot unwinding with a relentless pace and some style. You become acclimatised to the squealing horror of the film at roughly the same speed that The plot develops, which is smart, and it has a climax worthy of all the credit the film has received. It's a clever film, blending blood and plot to titillate you even beyond the final credits, as you mentally piece together the loose ends - and they all fit together rather nicely. I enjoyed it immensely, but it took me a while to realise it. Its a bit like Seven in as much as its dark and hard to predict, and like Seven I realised that this time the film maker has got one one over on me.

title: one of the top scariest
review: I loved this movie because it was so scary. You didn't know what was going to happen next. I love the twist at the end. It's unreal how the girl that barely made it out alive in part one became a part of the horror in part two. High ratings for this one. I would recommend anyone watch this movie. You will jump out of your seat. I think that the characters did a wonderful job of sticking with the part they were supposed to play. I can't believe that Donnie didn't make it out alive.
