title: The Saw movies are just the best!!
review: I own both the Saw movies.. I'm in love wit them quite frankly its my favorite movie and I find Saw 2 to be better than Saw 1 despite the fact it was kinda rushed and shorter. Jigsaw plays well in the movie his acting is jus incredible I think they did a great job using him throughout the movie to make it a success to let us know the real reason of what he does.Donnie Wahlburg I thought played his part well... even though hes not one your talented actors and he came from a popular boy band he did good in this movie...but stupid of him not following the rules... all he had to do was listen to Jigsaw and coulda saw his son. Parts I didn't like in the movie was the people playing the game were just plain stupid they didn't take it seriously... compare to Saw 1 Adam and Dr. Gordon took it seriously and tryed to figure everything out.. but these people were plain dumb.. only smart ones were Amanda(well we know why) and Daniel.The twist at the end... well i didn't expect it.... it was unpredicatable in my eyes... i never thought the tape wasn't live and jus VCR and his son was behind Jigsaw the whole time and Amanda turns out to be behind the whole thing... kinda realized that part when she made those eyes at Daniel... but anyways Saw 2 is a better movie and I think more unpredicatable....Get the Saw movies and enjoy!!

title: Inferior to the original but contains similar mind-blowing plot-twists
review:
Decent sequel to the brilliantly horrific "Saw". At the start of the film Jigsaw has eight would-be victims captured in a house together, with various riddles and traps to negotiate if they hope to escape. Whilst we see them all busy being tormented by Jigsaw's trickery, and one another, Jigsaw himself has been caught by the police, at his own hideout. Wahlberg plays Detective Matthews, who, with his police pals, is trying to extract from Jigsaw the whereabouts of the house to save his son, who is one of the eight trapped.

The movie clicks along alternating between these two broad aspects. The far better of these are the scenes outside of the house. As Jigsaw and Matthews progress their cat-and-mouse interaction we learn about Jigsaw's motivation and history, and Tobin Bell is near-perfect in this role, just utterly cold and creepy. Wahlberg's performance is only decent, certainly not great, but probably didn't need to be anything more given that this part of the movie is all about Jigsaw in any case.

The scenes in the house in the main feel like padding out time in anticipation of a big finish. We learn almost nothing about most of the captured, to the extent that most of them didn't really need to be given a name beyond "victim #3" or such. This pretty much applies to the first four characters killed.

The traps or their links to their intended victims mostly aren't as clever as those in the original, and this stuff has certainly lost some of its impact and almost become gimmicky in the sequel. Still this is a horror movie, and if you can't respond to what you'll see with "cooool" you're probably in the wrong theatre anyway. My stomach did turn in delight at the truly horrible scene involving the character Amanda (who returns from the original) in the "pit", about halfway through the movie. Worth making an effort to get through your munchies before it. Better still don't attempt to eat and watch - the opening scene of the film is also deliciously gruesome.

A few people die, a few don't, and the movie does build to a big finish and two big final twists. Not much can be said without giving it away, suffice to say the last five minutes were brilliant, and, like the first film leave you thinking "oh yeah.... so that's why that happened". Particularly the twist involving Wahlberg's son....wow. I was taken aback by the cleverness of the writers and the little hints along the way which didn't seem to mean anything at the time. The ending, and the performance of Bell, really did make this movie and for me saved it from being average to poor horror schmaltz.

You do need to see the original first to best appreciate this movie.

Frustrating to review really given that I can't say much about the best thing about the movie, the ending. The way the story has been left after this one, I can envisage Saw III being an absolute disaster. We shall see....

title: A great sequel to a good first movie
review:
Some of the reviewers haven't seen much of Becker, a superb long running comedy starring Ted Danson, or they would recognise Amanda as Linda from it...she is a great actress and plays her part well here, so it wasn't just a bit part in the first film and bigger part here...she has been around a while.

OK, the horror is all gore, no suspense and with no scenes to make you jump. Whenever a character had a "way out" it was obvious a nasty surprise awaited him or her. The Sixth Sense had these qualities- my favourite film for sudden scares, and my favourite film of all time actually...

The ending leads the way to Saw III and it couldn't be worked out by anyone, I imagine, because it seems a bit ridiculous, but hey, you have to leave your reality sense at the door anyway!

If you liked Saw I then this is a film to watch, every bit as good, if not better.

title: Best, Bloodiest Movie Ever
review: This is the greatest movie of all time. It's bloody, gory, gruesome and everything else you would want or need in a good horror movie. I don't understand why people can't watch this type of movie. It's not like the people in the games suffered very long. So what's the big deal? Who wouldn't want to watch and hear people (in a horror movie, of course) kicking and screaming their way out of death. And what's with Beverly Mitchell's death? She died in a freaking hallway with absolutely no blood relating to her death. Why didn't they give her a bloody game? She always plays the stupid little "tehe" roles, like Seventh Heaven? Come On!! I will admit that the guy who burned in the oven was pretty disturbing. Needles, not so bad. Razers, meh! She was already going to die soon anyways. The key thing with mask was suspenseful and well-thought out. But it was too similar to the bear-trap in the first Saw, in my opinion. Overall, great movie!! Can't wait to see the third one. I'll be first in line.

title: Nowhere near as good as comments would lead you to believe
review: I had a soft spot for the first Saw, which went away after I saw it a second time. This one didn't even generate the goodwill that I have for nearly all horror movies. While there are a few sequences that are good, that are especially horrifying, there are a few major drawbacks. The characters are almost entirely two-dimensional. The methods of creating depth to characters seems to be that they'll deliver a hint at a back story, but there's little to no acting involved. Only one of the secondary characters has any traits. The situation is painful to watch because the people seem to be entirely ineffective individuals. The second problem is that the ending betrays the biggest point of the series - the villain (who has reached cartoonish super-villainy) breaks the rules of his character by performing an (implied) straightforward murder. Yes, it's passable for a rental, but it is hardly re-watchable.

title: Adult version of Willy Wonka
review: I couldn't help but notice a similarity to Willy Wonka. They both contained a guide thru the environment, were punished for their bad choices, inability to follow direction, rudeness and self centeredness and were rewarded for their compassion and trying to play by the rules. In both movies you slowly see the rude and disobedient people get sucked up a tube or down a drain in Willy Wonka and burned to death or have their head shot off in Saw II. At the end of each movie only the guide and the polite well behaved person survive. In Saw II they don't realize they have a guide among them, but Amanda and Willy Wonka are supervising the tour and are in control and the others are observed after being given the rules and punished and rewarded accordingly.

title: Oh Yes...There Will Be Blood.
review: This was a insane movie,all the cool traps that Jigsaw did for the people to survive his game.And the traps were really cool like the Venus-Fly Trap.And The Neddles in the Pit,the Arm Trapper,the Oven,and the gun shot key-hole.In Saw 1 it didn't show Jigsaw or his real name,but in here we knows this time who he is.This is better than Saw 1 because less traps and victims means not so good.The more the creepier this movie gets to become.This also makes us learn a lesson,if you don't appreciate life than you don't deserve life,a good lesson for all of us.Now we know we should appreciate life or we will be in Jigsaws' games.And in every ones mind is,is Jigsaw dead or alive.And is Matthews' father going to be in Saw 3 or not.I like this movie a best horror movie created,thank-you because now we know we want to see Saw 3.I Know I will love Saw 3 100%.

title: 'Saw'ing Again
review:
Gory and violent, but exciting and fun sequel to the 2004 thriller has the serial killer, Jigsaw, locking a group of strangers in a booby-trapped house. The group must work together to try and escape before a deadly gas kills them.

Donnie Wahlberg plays the detective on the case, and Shawnee Smith reprises her role from the first "Saw" as Amanda. The devices Jigsaw creates are clever, especially the one in the opening sequence. The conclusion. though, doesn't seem to be as surprising as its predecessor's.

However, the conclusion also leaves the door open for another sequel.

title: Cleverer and Better Than The First!!!!
review:
Saw had a brilliant story line and a great twist at the end. When i went to see Saw 2 i did not have high expectations. I found the director made a great job out of this movie. Jigsaw's traps are well thought out and the idea of about 8 people trapped in a house and all have different tasks to find out antidotes is very clever. The house idea is very much like the film "Cube" but in many ways Saw 2 is much better.

I think Saw 2 is much better than the first because there are much stronger performances by the leading characters and i think overall the film had been spent more time on than the original!!

Great Movie and a must see in my opinion!

title: Hard but Amazing
review:
Just imagine how hard it is to have THAT many characters in ONE BUILDING and for a film to only go for 93 minutes, the captivation, the action, the writing, the directing.... it was amazing. Just amazing how it was done. So short, with a group of characters only and in the space of 93 minutes.... to carry on from an original as well... just awesome work here.

Especially with almost unknown cast members, we know Ronnie and a fair few of us will of known Beverley Mitchell, but the rest I didn't know and it was just great. Yet another great installment for the series and if you watched carefully at the end of saw II you'll of realised there IS room for another..

title: We could've done without a sequel to Saw but it was still good to have that sort of entertainment!
review: Okay I'm like the ultimate thriller fan but i found this movie more gruesome than scary. It still kept me in suspense tho...and i love the twist that involves time...(think video). Its brilliant writing...except for the ending. I didn't like end twist at all...it wasn't really...satisfying...i guess! It just didn't do it for me. OK so now i just read the bit about writing a minimum of 10 lines...OK well personally the first one was awesome...the sequel we couldn't have done without...but it was still alright to watch...and to think that Aussies wrote the script...pure Aussie talent! Too bad they couldn't film it in Australia tho...we're sooo poor...lol! OK well I've already said this before but i absolutely love thrillers....i love scaring myself...so much that when I'm home alone, i turn off all the lights and watch thrillers all night! I actually watched Saw and Saw2 back to back when it was just me and my friend at home for the night...its the way to go!!!

title: WHOA>>>> What A Film
review:
Damn, this film ROCKS!! I just watched on Pay Per View and worth every cent. You cannot say that about many PPV films. I was blown away not having seen Saw. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED The next one will be in October 2006 No doubt trying to get it ready for Halloween as they did this one but they had problems with finding the right director and more writers. They must have shot both 2 and 3 together or one after the other.

This film was almost non-stop and has you on the edge the length of the film. The cutting (editing) rhythm was just right for the action, almost like a rock video but with scenes that have clues all over the place. And the wrap up happens so fast that it leaves your head spinning, like did I just see what I thought I saw? Total surprising film with the twist and turns we all look for. I promise you will love this film.

title: You won't relax during this movie
review:
The Director together with the writers worked a perfect combination. It is awesome, the effects, the extras, the props, it's all worked perfectly.

The plot is (again) built around some people locked up in a house constantly inhaling a toxic gas, similar to the the gas used in the "Tokyo attacks". The aim of the "game" is to successfully acquire the antidote, of which several samples are hidden around the house.

Easy? Simple? Believe me, nothing's harder. What do the kidnapped people have in common? Do they EVEN HAVE anything in common? How can a cancerous person work out all those traps? Apart from some flaws and the apparent ingenuity of the people inside the house, this movie is a masterpiece.

Can't wait for Saw 3

title: For pure nasty torture, let's make people with weak stomachs watch this.
review:
For most of "Saw II", it only seems related to the first one in the remotest way possible. But don't worry, it'll all become clear. This one has a bunch of people waking up inside a house, having no idea how they got there. A disembodied voice tells them that there's a chemical killing them, and they have to find the keys to the antidote. If only they knew what awaits them.

In the grand scheme of things, maybe "Saw II" is an excuse to be gross. The first one was really gruesome, and we all know that sequels are more extreme. But this movie does have a certain charm to it, even if it uses some unpleasant stuff to get there. You might say that these movies look at how things are interconnected. I know, that's a real stretch. But I still assert that it's worth seeing...if you have a strong stomach.

title: watch and see!!
review: Having seen the first Saw, I wasn't sure how they could build on it. I waiting with trepidation to watch this! I was pleasantly surprised. Whilst it wasn't as good as the first film, it was very good. The imagination is excellent, the deaths of those held are as gruesome as the first movie but perhaps not as shocking because I've seen the first film. Donnie Wahlberg plays the detective well and the morality, if a lot twisted, is there to see. There's a bit of a twist near the end which I won't go into. If you liked the first one, you'll enjoy this one. If you haven't seen the first one... be warned, it's not for the faint hearted! I really liked the way they interlinked both films. I'd say a must see especially the needle bit!!!!!

title: Good movie; not great, but good. Third movie may mean room for redemption in the eyes of some---
review:
The first movie, although extremely gruesome, was brilliant. It showed us just how much people take life for granted--- all of us do, there isn't a single soul who can fairly and rightly say that they had never at least once in the most tiny way taken advantage of the life they were given.

This movie, although not quite meeting the expectations of many, was good. Great? That's all a matter of opinion of every individual. But it WAS good.

There wasn't a whole lot of character development--- we basically learned that each person did this or that in their past, and how they were connected--- through Daniel's dad. They all had evidence planted against them by his dad. Really, it was only the kid (Daniel) and the girl (Amanda) that I wanted to live. Why? Well, because Daniel is what he is--- a kid. Not a little four year old kid, but still not an adult. Amanda? Because she at the moment seemed to be the only one who actually was willing to do anything to survive Jigsaw's game.

The characters were way bad. This one guy goes around killing people or leaving them to their deaths... doesn't make much sense to do so at the start. Wouldn't it be smarter to keep them around to help you find an antidote, and then kill them so you will ultimately be the survivor? But he goes around and bashes them on the head and what not.

The movie was good, but it has a lot of room for improvement. I have to say that I didn't expect the ending--- I really didn't believe that Amanda would carry on Jigsaw's torture game for those taking advantage of life. I just thought, oh, so she escaped but returned to her taking-advantage-of-life-ways and he brought her back. Then we learn that she in fact, is the new Jigsaw. And it makes sense--- in a weird way. She survived it, so she knew it was possible. She was already once a drug addict and in jail, so nobody ever accused this girl of being some brilliant genius of a human being in the first place. And Jigsaw always had to have a front row seat, remember? Amanda, starting on her very first 'game', had a front row seat. She was one of the supposed victims stuck in the house.

There are a few things we have to consider--- Jigsaw had cancer, so he was dying. Was it likely for him to fix that house up so that it had all sorts of traps like before? Not likely. What is most likely is that Amanda, with some help, did it all. Either that, or it was done before the game. Amanda and Daniel were in the bathroom that we first saw in the original Saw movie--- so its possible the whole place was rigged for different times, different games set up for different people caught by Jigsaw taking advantage of life.

As I said, this movie wasn't great. It had its flaws just like all movies usually do--- but its still worth a watch at least once, when you're considering what movie to rent. Or if you just see it on a movie channel--- its not something you will always want to watch over and over. Its something you should for sure want to see once. The rest is all just... a matter of opinion.

This movie left an opening for a sequel, with the new Jigsaw. This was Amanda's first game... she has room to improve, and by the third movie if they do follow through with it, she should have already gone through with the game a few times before the movie starts. A good movie with flaws, and has room for redemption.

title: One instance where the sequel is much better.
review: This is one of the movies that was better than the original... that doesn't say much, but still... also, one of the few movies to break the cycle of "Great soundtrack, crappy movie." I will tell you now, however... if you don't want to see gore buildup over an hour and a half, don't watch this, but if you are looking for a story with a decent twist (WAY better than the first movies... I could see that from a mile away.) then I recommend this... also, I am happy that they didn't give me a reason to hate one of my favorite Mudvayne songs, on the soundtrack ("Forget to Remember" from the Lost and Found CD). and this time, they had ACTORS! The first movie, the best actors were Glover, Bell, and Potter... but this one had many more... I thought it was good, I think you will too.

title: More Saw. More gore. Result is poor.
review:
Saw was an inventive low-budget shocker that ultimately succeeded due to its clever narrative and ability to disgust.

Despite attempts to emulate the elements that made the original work so well, Saw 2 fails to successfully repeat the formula, ultimately feeling like a quickie cash-in sequel (albeit with better acting).

The story is basically a retread of the first film, but this time around twisted sicko Jigsaw wreaks havoc on a larger group than before. These protagonists act with little or no logic, undermining any tension wrought from their situation and, in some places, their stupidity beggars belief (the oven victim and the girl who reaches inside the perspex were particularly moronic).

I also found the direction and editing extremely tiresome; so many horror films these days feel the need to add choppy edits, distressed and grainy effects and hand-held camera shots. Such gimmicks are not necessary if the director has a tight control of his film and the script is strong enough. These showy techniques make me feel like the movie makers are trying to detract the audience from the lack of a great plot.

I sat to the end of this one hoping that the final denouement would be sufficiently clever and unexpected for me to forgive what had gone before - it wasn't!

title: Obnoxious and irritating
review: When "Saw" first came out in 2004 there was much buzz surrounding the film. Some called it the goriest film ever made and the premise sounded intriguing. I so saw the film with some expectation and was very let down. The good plot had so many missed opportunities and the acting was dreadful all around, it also did not help that James Wan is such a poor director and used way too many MTV-music video style directing techniques. But it made a butt-load of money and one of Lionsgate Films highest cost to profit films. It also made way for many more extremely gory horror films like "High Tension", "Wolf Creek", "Hostel", and the remake of "The Hills Have Eyes". It also brought along "Saw II", which is just as bad. Since i thought that the gore was not all gross in "Saw", they really upped the anti with "Saw II", its just one sick movie. I know some people really love these movies and others wanted to be shocked when they first see it so I wont say anything more. I could not believe it when I was watching it but the acting in the second film is even worse. Maybe some of the worst I have ever seen. Screaming does not count as acting, its just annoying. Also the Darren Lynn Bounsson directs this as if he was directing a punk rock music video. The result is so obnoxious that it's hard to sit through. I do have to give "Saw II" some credit because the story is not half bad, the twist is better and I was surprised how well they linked the two stories. But besides that there is no redeeming value to this piece of garbage. "Saw II" is ultimately an obnoxious and irritating movie going experience, at least for me. Genre fans no doubt love his film and I can't blame them, they are the ones Lionsgate Films made this for and the target audience loves it. But for me, this is one of the worst films I have seen from the year 2005.

title: Decent sequel, gore and blood ala plenty, never lacks creativity thanks to Whannell
review:
**1/2 Donnie Wahlberg, Shawnee Smith, Tobin Bell, Erik Knudsen, Dina Meyer, Franky G, Glenn Plummer. Directed by Darren Lynn Bousman

Despite the doubt of a sequel surpassing the original (which it doesn't) or the attempt to measure up, "Saw 2" does. Leigh Whannel going out on a limb with out James Wong but substituting for him director Darren Lynn Bousman. A fine choice indeed. This time friendly serial killer and life teacher Jigsaw (Bell) pits eight strangers in a house while they breathe in deadly nerve agents. While Detective Mathews attempts to hunt down his son who is also one of the eight. "Saw 2" doesn't fail on blood and creativity but it does the exact opposite, it brings wholesome torture and life back to killings on the screen. Most horror films fail to deliver the goods or a decent story line, "Saw 2" packs both. No it's not as good as the original but a lot better than I would think for what it is. My final rating 7/10

title: Almost as good as the first
review:
A bunch of people wake up and groggily get to their feet. They're in a creepy looking room. They don't know each other. Then they're informed they have to find a way out of the house in a matter of hours, or the nerve gas they've been inhaling will strike 'em dead as a doornail. Naturally, some booby traps aim to prevent this.

This follow up to the 2004 original could have lapsed into typical sequelitis and just been terribly derivative and dull. You know the drill: Kill a whole slew o' people in horrible, disgusting ways that in no way further the plot. But Saw II doesn't quite stoop that low. The horrible, disgusting killings do indeed further the plot.

I am reminded of an old radio program called The Shadow. You might recognize the name, since Alec Baldwin played the titular hero in a 1994 movie. But it began in radio, and there was one episode called "The House That Death Built." In the episode, people were offed in creative ways by booby traps, such as a gas chamber and a series of shotguns.

It's usually difficult to translate the unseen horror, like radio can, to a full-length feature film, and indeed most movies fail to do so. But Saw II does do so. You know right away these aren't characters we're meant to find appealing, or root for. No needless attention is paid to their backgrounds; all that you get on each character is all that you need to put things together. No dialog is especially wasted, and that - along with the always-fun gore - is what makes this movie work.

Of course, if you don't like blood in your film, you're going to really hate this one. It's everywhere. People spurt from all sorts of orifices, plus some new ones. But things don't seem to be done with the intent to shock, another point in the movie's

title: Definitely better then the first.
review: Usually the sequels never beat the prequels. In this case, it truly does. Saw had lots of flaws, and Saw II was near perfect. There's definitely more gore, more blood, and more thought in Saw II. Saw II's ending is as twisted as the first. With a house instead of an ancient bathroom, the poor people stuck in it actually get to roam around. There is definitely more twists in Saw II, and more to think about. We find out what makes Jigsaw tick, and why he puts a jigsaw on each of his victims. This is a fantastic movie, well thought together and guaranteed to shock you in at least one way. It will make you scared to the bone, and fear being in dark enclosed spots, or opening doors.

title: A great follow up for the saw series
review: Saw II is one of the best thriller/horrors i have seen well since saw. Jigsaw takes 8 unsuspecting people and puts them in a booby trap filled house. One of them is Daniel Matthews son of Eric the detecive that is watching all of this happen back at jigsaws lair where the madman has been caught but he tells Matthews that he wants to play a game and if he does he will see his son sit and talk that is it. When people in the house start dieing one by one there are so many twist and turns and the end of the movie you totally through you off guard. All I can say is that I was blown away and I didn't think i would see another movie as good as saw until I saw II. my vote is a ten out of ten because there was a lot more blood a lot more twists and a purely genius ending

title: Surprisingly good sequel
review:
I knew this would be good when I rented it on DVD. I didn't think it would be this good! Saw II is the sequel to the 2004 horror flick Saw. Detective Mason finds Jigsaw after another murder. Mason has to join Jigsaw's game when he finds out his son is in the game with another bunch of people.

This one has way more traps than the original Saw. The hand trap, the needle pit, and more! There are so many new and interesting traps. I really liked this movie. It was violent and gruesome and freaky, but that's why it's called a horror movie. A movie called Saw II has to be really violent. C'mon! Saw! You know what's weird? I don't think anyone even uses a saw in this one, unlike the first one.

8/10. Really enjoyed this one. Fun movie.

title: All That I Had Hoped For
review: I didn't get a chance to see this movie in the theater and was greatly anticipating it coming out on DVD. I rented it the day it came out because where I live, you can never find new releases on the weekend. Anyway, I put this DVD into my HD up-conversion DVD player and watched it with my HDTV and surround sound. Holy Crap! This movie was everything it should be. There was a great level of suspense and what happens in the last 15 minutes was so awesome. It is not often that I see a movie that I can honestly say "What a great, great movie!" I strongly recommend this movie for any Saw or horror movie fans. It was all that I had hoped for.

title: OH yes...there was blood
review: holy god that was a good movie. What a ride, what a ride. This was a horror flick. It seems rare to have a horror flick have a great sequel, but they did an awesome job. How twisted of a mind do you have to have in order to write this and think this stuff up. I want to throw a girl into a pool of needles and one has the cure. F'n sweet man. I will admit i was scared to see "The new kid" in this movie, but he did a good job. I was looking for the famous saw twist, and then WAM! There is was! My jaw dropped as i started to realize what was going on. I wont give it away if you haven't seen it, but if you haven't then your stupid. GO SEE IT...RENT IT! (your not stupid..just slow, its OK) Was it just me or did anyone catch the Shining reference? Guy going crazy in a house..killing people..was that just me?

title: Love it!
review:
I really do love everything about this movie. i think the story was amazing. i mean i cant think of something like that even though I'm good at writing. the end of the movie shocked me, like i have to say i was expecting the ending to happen, i was just like OMG!!! this movie wasn't scary....it was just very disturbing and gory. but what i loved about it most...other then dumb stories like when a stranger calls...is that Jigsaw had such a deep reason for inflicting this upon people...and he really is clever. i read some people say that the people trapped in the house were dumb...and in some very small ways i guess they were...but its true that the writer had to be smart to think of this storyline because can u really say that you would have figured everything out just like that? their brains were being infused with this retarded gas...and they woke up to find themselves in the state that they were in. like...if i were in that position before watching this,....i would be going insane...like seriously...my brain wouldn't be able to function.

i really hated the drug dealer guy..when he started going crazy...but like he didn't want to kill anyone....(he was still a ass)..he wanted to see the numbers on the baq of their head and he didn't want to tell them about it because there was only one antidote in the safe.

but yeah over all....this movie is crazy i wasn't expecting the ending to happen....i think jigsaw is crazy and the everything he said was just to clever...the whole game was pretty clever. the only thing left to say is that the detective just shouldve listened to Jigsaw and his partner as well..he wouldn't find himself trapped that way.

title: Keeps you on the edge of your seat!
review: I could not wait for this to come out on DVD and Saw II does not disappoint one bit. Continuing his brutality from the first Saw, Jigsaw (Tobin Hall)is back, locking several people in a room including stars like Franky G (Confidence) and Glenn Plummer (The Day After Tomorrow), as well as the son of Detective Eric Mathews, (Donnie Wahlberg). In the beginning, Jigsaw is captured by the police, but that is all part of his evil game. He shows police monitors that see the victims, who are trapped inside a house which has traps all over it, plus the people are being poisoned by a gas and only a few antidotes are placed in the house. In this 92-minute thriller, you are on the edge of your seat as you watch the people try to figure a way out while Mathews trys to recover his son alive.

title: To draw first blood is good, but second blood is much more amusing
review:
After seeing the awesome thriller of the original "Saw" I was ready for anything the creators could throw at us for the second... or so I thought. In the sequel, the ante's been upped and the game has become much more twisted.

The unique game has now stretched out to eight unlucky players who must face the "Final Round" in which the succeed... or die trying. Just as the commercials and posters say, "There will be blood." But that's not all! As the game unfolds a cop now searches for his son in a "Bonus Round" that's bound to lead him to the darkest corners of his own mind.

I recommend this flick for anyone who liked the first one, or who like a good graphic bloody gory murder scene... come on, admit it, I know I do. If you've got a serious blood lust, this movie's the one for you!

title: good movie (read review)
review: whoever said sequels don't live up 2 the first movie.may be true sometimes but saw2 had a far crazier ending,more twisted games ,and more elaborate deaths. This movie is definitely not scary neither is the first 1 .So for all u wusses out there its not scary.Beileve me i,m 11 years old.also there's a lot more cool traps and even more violence . See it w/ your kids over 12 that like scary movies.It contains strong violence,language and some very brief sexual references that will go way over kids heads.this movie is awesome and screw the critics!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!This is a good movie,i'd know I've seen many movies and many horror movies.Also this movie teaches some good life lessons and so does the first movie.

title: Very good, but not as satisfying as the first
review:
** Minor Spoilers **

I'm not the type that likes shocker horror films - just not my thing. I also loathe "dead teenager movies" where the point is to see how a gaggle of teens can be killed off, one-by-one, in increasingly sensational ways. So after researching Saw I was excited to see something that was more suspense mixed with a little horror - and to my surprise and delight is was a wonderful film, properly gritty with just enough gore (mostly off-camera) to let you know what happened without making you watch it.

Saw II is not that kind of movie. While it has most of the flavor of the first, and even a couple of characters return (both alive and dead), there is much, much, more gore here. In fact, many of the puzzles seem to be to inflict torture and pain than to present any solvable situation - and we get to watch every agonizing moment of it.

The endgame is extremely clever and satisfying - I never saw it coming. So, although glad I watched Saw II, I thought the deliberate bent toward the 'dead teenager' genre a cop-out in direction. Saw III is listed for a Halloween 2006 release - hopefully it will bend more toward the original than this one.

title: Good Gory Movie Fare
review:
I must say that Saw II did not disappoint. For those of you not familiar with the original Saw, it was about a serial killer who puts victims in situations where they kill themselves in their efforts to get out. It was a masterful movie, a taut, tense, psychological thriller, with a sense-jarring, rug-out-from-under-you, sixth sense type ending.

It was also unrestrictedly gory, and what was good about it was that the gore added to the tenseness of the story, instead of distracting you from it. I was afraid that the sequel would still be okay as a story, but nowhere near the original's impact.

I was not disappointed. Saw II avoids most pitfalls of sequels, such as following the same basic storyline, the same sorts of stunts, and just making it bloodier and more action filled. The original Saw was made up of mostly flashbacks with calls back to the present time, where the main story was. It was a very creative way to tell a story, and the second one told it in a creative way also. Of course, it is a sequel, so it is not as good, but the filmmakers did not, to their credit, attempt to make it more bloody, or more action-filled. The traps Jigsaw (the main bad guy) sets for his patients are more creative, but not to the point of trying to completely outdo the original. The filmmakers have a clear understanding that, as a sequel, they cannot hope to overshoot the original, no matter how hard they try, so they do not try too hard like so many people do. All in a all a wonderful story, though it is not for the weak of stomach, as it is filled with gore. Another thing I liked about the sequel was that the ending was also sixth sensish. Here's some advice to those of you who have yet to see one or both of them: Don't preoccupy yourself with trying to figure out the story. Ride the whole thing with the characters, and let the realizations come to you as they come to them. You will enjoy the storyline much more if you immerse yourself in what they are feeling instead of analytically analyzing every detail to figure out the plot twist. Go see Saw II, and if you haven't seen the first, go see the first, and then the second. I definitely suggest seeing the first one first, because the effect of the ending in the second one is all the more enhanced if you see the first beforehand. These are two wonderful masterpieces of gore-film-making, while still effectively focusing on proper character development, a rarity in most Hollywood horror flicks. These are definitely not films to miss if you are a movie fan, and especially if you're a gore/horror fan.

title: SAW 2 is a rare sequel that even comes close to the original.
review: SAW 2 is every bit as good as the original. In fact, the only reason i didn't give it a 10 is because then it would be the perfect movie. If i find the perfect movie, i won't have anything else to do. And today where all we see movie wise is kids movies, the same love stories over and over again, and a bunch of remade horror films, it's nice to have something new. SAW gave us something new and SAW 2 continues to deliver. Some may say that it is merely a remake of the first, but i believe there is sufficient new material and interesting twists that clearly make it stand on its own. I only hope they consider making it a trilogy!

title: Not one of the best, THE BEST horror movie of 2005
review: This movie may be very bloody and gory and not for the faint at heart, but it is truly brilliant. The Saw series so far is in my opinion the greatest movie series of all time. The overall movie was better than the first, but the so called twist ending wasn't as good. Don't get me wrong it was still good, but not as good. The acting was better than the first. There was a lot more of Jigsaw (Tobin Bell), who did a great job. From beginning to end you won't want to leave your seat, I know I didn't. This movie was simply phenomenal, I can't wait for it to come out on DVD. I'll definitely be buying it and I recommend it to everybody else out there.

title: Nice Sequel
review: As far as horror movie sequels are concerned, this is one of the better ones. It is not your typical comedy horrors like Friday The 13th, Nightmare On Elm Street, etc., but it has some really good elements to it. The opening scene is excellent, more towards reality than the cavalier attitudes of the "victims" from the first movie. The rest of the movie is all in the subtleties of suggestion, clues and manipulation that gives this movie a good viewing. Unfortunately, the characters are not exactly intelligent. I suppose that fear removes all sense of logic and makes seemingly intelligent people not notice/listen to clues or words that are given. The "victims" are your typical "i'll do stupid things until I die" type of people. The ending is excellent though, very nicely done. It is a good movie to watch.

title: Gore galore
review: SAW II is an improvement over the original SAW, as a group of young people and adults find themselves trapped in Jigsaw's house of horrors. The traps and deaths are clever, the gore quotient is upped, and the action never stops for a second. Add to this the fact that the cops have found and captured Jigsaw almost from the outset, but find themselves powerless to stop his latest game. Shawnee Smith and Tobin Bell are back from the original, and the ending of this ties itself back directly to the original in a highly satisfying manner. Highly recommended for gore hounds who thought HOSTEL and HIGH TENSION were too tame.

title: More cohesive, gorier and brutal than the original
review: Much better than the original. More cohesive, less contrived, more brutal. Tobin Bell is solid as the unmasked Jigsaw and manages to elicit a shred of empathy. The premise is similar to the first (several characters search for an exit before death visits), but there are enough surprise revelations, gory, inventive confrontations and a moody score to keep the structure from becoming predictable. Directed by Darren Lynn Bousman and written by Bousman and James Whannell, one of the original's writers, it connects directly with the first film while expanding on the concept. Climax is frantic and final image is one of grisly horror. Made by true horror fans for true horror fans. A fine achievement considering how many plates it's juggling.

title: the cute clown is back with saw II and it's great twist!!!
review: I really can't believe it!! i saw it just 4 or 5 hours ago and i still feel that i have enjoyed a great movie. 7 out of ten is way too low for such a film, 8 or 81/2 is OK... i mean OK.. i was shocked in the beginning with the scene with the guy having a key inside his head but the rest of it was just amazing, it had a great plot and the acting was outstanding. i believe it was a good point that they put back in ''Amanda'' because she sort of knew how to help. saw 1 might be better because it shows more disgusting things and has a little more suspense but saw II has a huge and great twist(better than saw 1 twist). don't miss this film!!! it might not make your life happier but if you are OK with gore and blood you will enjoy it... saw III really will look stupid but that's what people thought about saw II and they were completely wrong. it was great(except the white guy with the white shirt-bad acting). From me 8/10 as a thank you for giving to me and my friend a great and enjoyable evening...

title: Diagnosis: Sick!
review:
My review contains some spoilers (and even major ones for SAW, the prequel). This is obviously one of those movies you can enjoy most when you know the least of them in advance. So, if you didn't see it yet and just want to know if it rocks - it does! Go watch it and stop reading HERE.

The surprise is gone. We all know by now, who the Jigsaw killer is. His final entrance in SAW was the last and biggest jaw-dropper of the movie, opening the most brutal ending I can remember - "Game over", and then Adam screaming in the dark - it's not always the most violent moment that gives you the biggest creeps. John's identity no longer being secret is a typical sequel problem and most of us probably were curious, how that would be solved without falling behind the thrill established by the predecessor.

SAW II selects an offensive and very successful approach. By having the police "capture" John early in the movie, by placing him before our eyes right from the start, it makes clear: this is not about finding the killer, this is not about hunting the killer, this is not about someone puzzling about who the killer may be. Which artful discriminates from the prequel, and at the same time leads to the same old well known question: what is this actually all about? So while Eric tries to figure out the location of his son and the imprisoned people try to find their way out or to the cure, the viewer feels, the viewer knows, that there is more beneath the surface, that there's some master-plan behind this apparently simple setting. And, of course, there is. This way, curiosity returns to a seemingly resolved plot.

SAW focused strongly on it's main characters Lawrence and Adam, partially Detective Tapp, made us like them, want them to succeed. Even when watching it these days, I still have to remind myself, that there will be no happy ending, that this is not the kind of movie where the protagonist hugs his little daughter and beloved-again wife in the end, accompanied by top-lofty music. SAW II does not create such feelings. You wouldn't actually grieve, when almost everyone involved (well, probably except Amanda ;)) would be killed. For several reasons.

Eric, the apparent main character, isn't likable at all, even long before we learn, why exactly we should dislike him. When it comes to the people in the house - we're not really given any chance to get to know them. Of course, there are the "rather good" and the "rather bad", but we receive almost no background, no personality, no development. Not even everyone's cassettes are played (or even found). The only thing that seems to matter about them, is some mysterious common ground, which furthermore turns out to be the reason they are here. John on his part wins either way. You're never worried about him. You never doubt, that he did see this coming, exactly like it does.

Such approach to character development can be viewed ambivalent. On the one hand - it serves the purpose. Going other ways than in SAW makes the sequel more than a repeating of the old scheme. And, as we learn later in the movie, most of those were really just meaningless pawns in a game, which itself was just one move in a bigger game - which is probably exactly the feeling the viewer should obtain. On the other hand - not having an attachment figure automatically reduces the tension, takes the possible fear factor. You're not afraid of what could be behind a door, if you don't really care about the one who opens it.

However, SAW II isn't much about being scary anyway, even less than SAW. The genre says "horror" - but this horror is not meant to scare, it is meant to shock. And shock it does. Not because it shows blood and violence, but by showing pain, by showing suffering - corporal and emotional. It's not just "you're hit" and then the one lies on the ground unconscious, covered by soft-focus. It's "you're hit" and then it actually hurts.

It shows hopelessness and desperation. It shows people acting in the face of death so proximate, you're almost past the tunnel and the light. The probably most unsettling sequence in SAW was right before Lawrence starts to saw off his foot. Not the sawing itself, but those seconds, when you see him freak out and know, what is about to come, when you sit there and go like "no, no, please not, please don't do this, don't" (just like Adam by the way). And afterwards, you see his pale skin, you see him shaking, you know he's bleeding to death. Those are the moments when a movie gets to you, when it makes you feel uneasy.

SAW II is full of such moments. Do you remember Dr. Silberman's short but great appearance in TERMINATOR 3 when he finally sees the terminator and flees in horror? Amanda's awakening in the house reminded me very much of that scene - of course without the humorous and with much greater agony factor. And since one identifies with old-known Amanda right from the start, her displayed desperate fear, that "oh no, not again!" feeling directly transfers to the viewer. Gooseflesh, again, when you least suspect it.

And, of course, SAW/II is about twists. So, the last 5-10 minutes turn everything upside down in a literally traditional and surprisingly surprising way. Even having guessed bits and pieces (but mostly discarded them since it seemed just too freaky), I was totally overwhelmed.

A very felicitous sequel and a very good movie. Diagnosis: Sick!

title: If you SAW the first, you have to see this.
review:
It is not every year that you get a sequel worthy of the first, not even to mention cinema, especially if the original was a mega sleeper hit such as SAW.

Most of us expected a lame, unintelligent piece of rubbish, rushed and made in production line fashion, merely created to cash in on the unexpected success of the first, some even expected it to be a pg13 rendering of the original.

Thank heavens we were all expecting the wrong thing.

Saw2 was unexpectedly good, and with its complex plot and claustrophobic cinematography it certainly kept me on the edge of my seat for most of the full duration of the film.

Yes it is quite bloody violent in a grisly way and extremely disturbing, but I should tell you that the blood and violence is not just there to shock, it serves the story and entertains the masochistic side of all.

I will not divulge anything about the movie only that...If you liked the first, you will love this so go and see this if this is your cup of coffee.

title: Oh, Yes there will be a lot of blood
review:
It's a movie that scared thousands of people senseless last year. Made on the cheap with two unknown, 20-something guys at the helm, Saw is the kind of horror movie that has re-defined what scary movies are all about An ultra-violent, industrial-strength piece of gore and guts, Saw's brutal, grimy rawness was a monster hit in 2004. From the get-go, the film's twisted storyline, rapid-fire editing and jarring soundtrack pushed audiences' tolerance to the limit. Full of incredibly unsettling images, sounds and action, director James Wan and writer Leigh Whannell hit pay dirt with their surprise mega-hit. The film's style -- a gory music video that wouldn't be out of place with industrial musicians like Nine Inch Nails or movies like Seven -- was nothing short of revolutionary. Everything from metal machines that threaten to rip a woman's jaw off, self-mutilation and sawing legs off are now gross-out classic moments. The combination of the film's gallows humor, shock violence and eerie tone brought the big bucks in.

After Saw grossed more than $100 million at the box office last year, it was inevitable a sequel would be released. Saw 2, co-written and directed by newcomer Darren Lynn Bousman, comes out this week. Wan is staying on as producer and Whannell is Saw 2's co-writer.

And oh yes, there will be blood. Lots of blood, according to Bousman.

"Saw was a dark, disturbing film. This film Saw 2 isn't a sugar-coated candy movie. It's an assault on the senses," promises Bousman.

"There will be a lot more blood; a lot more violence. It's a bigger game. You have no clue what's going on. We're also going to find out what makes Jigsaw tick." Jigsaw, the psychopathic serial killer taunting his victims with elaborate games that force people to kill each other, is the main focus of Saw 2. Picking up right after the first film, the significantly larger sequel stars Donnie Wahlberg (The Sixth Sense, Band of Brothers) and a significantly larger cast than the original.

Wahlberg plays Detective Eric Mason, a cop investigating the gory results of a brutal murder. All leads point to Jigsaw -- this time, there's much, much more at stake, including Mason's own son.

Instead of two main characters, there are eight people locked in a room that's gradually spewing out toxic nerve gas. The terrified group all have to figure out how to escape before the nerve gas kills them. Trouble is, Jigsaw has created an even more sadistic house of horrors this time around, full of booby traps and other devices that test the characters' sanity and survival.

Some rumored new gross-out moments? Automated gun fire, metal gougers and other instruments of torture.

Bousman is thrilled to be involved in Saw 2. Based on a script he wrote before Saw was released called The Desperate, Bousman says some of the best compliments he gets from Saw 2 is the fact some people come out of the movie enraged and upset. It is already receiving much attention for its strong violence, gore and horrifying images.

"If you liked the first film, you're going to love the second," says Bousman.

The director knows he's got big shoes to fill. But he says he's happy to have had a star like Wahlberg in his film -- a cast addition that gives the film a huge boost.

Bousman says he went out and rented Band of Brothers before filming began for Saw 2 and was hugely impressed with Wahlberg's performance: "I was just blown away. He has this presence about him." Bousman also says he's lucky to have had such a supportive studio like Lion's Gate backing him. The studio is known for pushing the envelope with movies, distributing other grisly cult hits like House of 1000 Corpses.

"Lion's Gate was amazing. They were so supportive," he says.

Bousman's future looks especially bright. After the huge success of Saw, he's crossing his fingers the sequel hits it big too at the box office.

"The most difficult part is living up to the first film. There were no expectations with The Desperate. This isn't the case with Saw 2. There are huge Web armies that loved Saw. There are higher expectations with Saw 2," he adds. The film gets two thumbs up. Okay, fingers.

It makes you say "Oh, my God!". And, like the first one (Saw), doesn't let you see too much of what will happen next. That is a good thing because saying at the end: "Oh, yeah, I've seen it coming" just makes you hate it. Good movie for the passionates, bad movie for the faint of heart.

title: Saw 2 is a strong follow up to its predecessor of 2004
review:
In a general sense, it's not uncommon for a sequel to take a swan dive head first into the floor (Cruel Intentions 2 as a prime example), so I have to admit that I was surprised with this film.

It seems the larger budget didn't take away from the "grungy" feel I saw in Saw 1, which was great for continuity alone. Having said that, the original story line is carried further throughout this film and developed into something a little meatier. Initially you could be mistaken and think you were watching another run of Lethal Weapon...fortunately not!

The cast was much larger this time around, as did the range of the sets and props used. And by props I mean booby-traps.

A fair share of blood and gore might keep you cringing a little, but I found it to be quite realistic which was pleasing in a weird kind of way. Don't bother watching this one unless you've seen Saw 1, and get ready for the twist.

This one rates 8/10 for me.

title: You saw it too ? ;-)
review:
A good year ago my friend made me watch the first one on DVD and I was pinned to the bed during the whole movie, especially with the surprising end ! That only to mention that expectations were high...

The second one we had to see in the movie theatre. Why ? To be even more scared... To watch terrified friends sitting next to you, buried in there "protecting coats"... To really have the SAW Experience !

Did it disappoint ? No. The film started off with an EYE-catching opening scene, revealing that "no, I'm not a serial killer, they do it to themselves" evil plans master Jigsaw is still alive and kicking !

Thanks to a hint left in the video message of Jigsaw's first new victim, police are able to track him down. And surprise surprise... Cancer is floating all around, but his brains don't seem to be affected. Are Jigsaw's murdering days over ? Not yet, shockingly our cancer man was expecting the police and oh yeah, he's got something planned for them. To sum up : the life of several people, stuck in a mystery house, depends on the good behaviour of Officer Tough Guy, starting off a series of actions leading to a yet again shocking end.

Saw II was as scaring as the first one, at times disgustingly grosse, over the top, but that's how we like it. Ow yeah, very handy to have seen the first one, otherwise you miss a lot of hints.

title: Underrated
review:
This movie is fantastic. It has everything that nowadays high-budget horror movies are seriously lacking: a great, complete and intense villain; realistic blood; unexpected scares and a great concept. For those of you who think Saw didn't deserve a sequel, or instead of it, that a sequel would mess up the first one, you're wrong. Saw II lead us to know what moves Jigsaw, it shows more of his great games. Every time I watch this movie, it gaves me chills. A brilliant sequel for a brilliant first part. It equals the first one and, in some aspects, it is way better.

Oh yes, there will be blood!

(I'd just like to say thanks to Gregg Hoffman (producer) for his awesome work. We will miss you as an important part of the puzzle. Thanks and rest in peace my friend.)

review: Saw2 still is one of my favorites, although it will never touch the flabbergasting plot-end of the first movie... And it does not have to...(what am I saying? I ended flabbergasted again, I suppose...) This is a different plot: a view inside the mastermind's kitchen... and it will not bring you any closer to what's REALLY going on! Even up-close and personal you'll find yourself TRICKED by the master... Things that cannot be constructed better, can -luckely enough- be constructed again! I must say that the after-effect of SAW2 is the same as in SAW: in the hours following after you finished the movie things pop up and you'll see clues which I will not mention here. What a great script these people wrote, almost like a musical piece of Bach: you feel tired when finished! Such an intelligent form of weaving and tricks of the mind... All because we want to fooled, won't we?

title: Saw II: Another Mediocre Sequel
review:
Sequels, especially to horror films, seem to pop up every year. Many are unnecessary, like the Halloween and Texas Chainsaw Massacre sequels. It is hard to judge these films on their own merits, especially while comparing them to the film they follow. Saw II is a very uneven film with many highlights, but also many downfalls.

For those who are not familiar with the plot of Saw, it is about a serial killer who puts his victims in life and death situations. For example, a character will wake up chained to a pipe and be forced to kill the person who is also chained across from him if he wants to live. If he does not commit the act within a certain timeframe, both of them will die.

In this sequel, Detective Eric Mason (Donnie Wahlberg) finds out his delinquent son is one of the few unlucky people forced to use their intellect and cooperation in a booby-trapped house. The catch is that all the victims have inhaled a nerve gas that will kill them within a few hours if they don't escape. Mason has to cooperate and play Jigsaw's "game" if he ever wants to see his son again.

The movie works well within the conventions of the horror genre. It has the violence and murders that the audience expects from horror films. The unique deathtraps in this movie will, doubtlessly satisfy gore-hungry fans.

The acting is also quite impressive for a horror film. All the actors seem to understand the parts they play and play them with great realism and human emotion. Wahlberg is believable as a detective who can't balance his work and troubled life. He depicts the pain of a father whose life seems to be at its worst. Tobin Bell is very creepy as Jigsaw. From his cold stares to his devious smile, this man, who considers himself a prophet, is quite obviously a psychopath and finds pleasure in seeing others fight for their lives.

The actor who is the most impressive out of the ensemble of victims in Jigsaw's game is Franky G, who plays a Puerto Rican drug dealer. The fact that the actor, who has a very macho physique and demeanor, plays him with such depravity and cowardliness lends a realistic desperation to the character: the scene where this is most evident is when he has to find a key in a pit that is filled with syringes in less than two minutes. Instead of going in himself, he throws a woman, who is a part of this group of victims, in without any thought.

The attempt of the director, Darren Bousman, and cinematographer, David Armstrong, at giving the film a low-budget look and feel should be applauded. While it is quite obvious that this movie had quite a hefty budget behind it (unlike the first film) the attempt comes with clear artistic intentions.

Unfortunately, not everything about this movie is milk and cookies. Quite a few aspects of the script are very poorly written. A few times, the technique of scaring through a "jump out of the closet" is used, which is quite annoying and gains absolutely nothing in terms of scares.

Another terrible aspect of this film is the scriptwriters' decision to reveal the killer, Jigsaw, so early in the movie and spoon feed the audience his motives.

What made him such a great character in the first film was the fact that the audience barely knew anything about him. In this movie, his motives are explained so clearly that it completely ruins what Jigsaw was all about. Imagine if Alfred Hitchcock had revealed Mrs. Bates in Psycho. Would the movie be worth watching? This unfortunate little detail takes away so much from the movie. It doesn't ruin it, but it is a detraction. He becomes a caricature instead of a character.

What's worse is the "twist" (if one could call it that) at the end of the movie. It just does not fit Jigsaw's profile. Without giving too much away, the end is completely unrealistic and dumb and contradicts the first movie.

It's hard to decide who should see Saw II. While the film is clearly for fans of the horror genre, it should be noted that this movie does not even come close to the psychological terror the original achieved so well.

This movie is, without question, for people who enjoy seeing lots of blood and violence and are perhaps even turned on by it.

For those who really loved the first one, it's hardly worth shelling out hard-earned cash to see the sequel. Perhaps these fans should instead wait for next Halloween and rent it.

Final Grade: C

title: A very gritty, violent, disgusting, brutal........ masterpiece?
review:
Plot: The Jigsaw killer returns, this time even more bad ass and sick than before. He decides to set up a few people inside a house, each room with a specific trap for a specific person. The people inside must find a way out, or the poisonous gas being put inside the room will kill them. Along the way, they must also find the antidotes to the poison in their lungs. Meanwhile, Detective Matthews must deal with the finally "caught" Jigsaw killer, is he wants his son to stay alive. Problem is, his son is in the house with all the traps, and Detective Matthews is losing his cool.

Review: Pretty damn good. The plot itself is decent, but if done the right way can be really really good. And, it is. The plot develops nicely, giving twists and turns along the way, and watching both sides of the situation became fascinating, quickly. I found myself listening intently almost the whole time, and the other times, I found myself squirming uncomfortably as the gorgeous gore brought itself out on screen. Which, of course, I loved.

The Characters, sadly, are under-developed, and really don't go anywhere, aside from being shot, stabbed, gassed, burned, cut, and smashed. They're also very cliché' characters we've all seen before, and, sadly, they seem rather flat. The character Xavien is way too quick to go crazy-psycho-killer, and it almost made me roll my eyes. The writer's seemed too quick to get on with the horror/gore, and decided not to let us know nor care about the characters, but rather watch them die in grisly ways. This, of course, is entirely different than in the original Saw, where we got to know the characters incredibly well. If it gave us a bit more time to get to know the characters, it would be better. Besides, we got some good ol' horror right from the beginning, that let me tell you, made me smirk evilly, at the same time squirm uncomfortably. I loved it.

Anywho, the editing directing and all that good stuff was done rather nicely. The director did a great job at giving a grimy sadistic feel to the film ,and I just love that. The editing was well done during the horrific situation sequences, but some times seemed a bit slow, or a bit too fast at other times. The cinematography was very stylized, like the original Saw, which I just love. It, also, gives a very different feel to the movie than you get with most others.

As for what we see in the movie, be prepared to close your eyes, clench your fists, and not feel in the mood to make-out (which, for me especially, is very hard to do :P ) and to squirm uncomfortably through-out 3/4 of the movie. Also, look forward to, not only one, but TWO twists through-out the movie. It's a pretty good shocker!

Overall I guess, to be fair, I must give it a 8/10 (the original got a big fat 9.5) because of the few issues it had, such as the sometimes poor editing, the rushed feeling of the beginning, and the cliché' unexplored characters. It also, as per usual, does not live up to the original, but is still pretty damn sweet.

Things to Beware: 1. Not everyone can act :\ 2. Cliché' characters 3. Some poor editing 4. Squirmy uncomfortable feeling No making out :P

Things to Look Forward to: 1. Squirmy uncomfortable feeling (if you like that) 2. Gruesome deaths 3. Nice twist at the end 4. A really really really really awesome, best scene of the movie opening sequence 5. Pretty damn good directing

OVERALL: 8.6/10

title: Two thumbs... umm, I mean fingers...up
review: Now a days it seems harder and harder to find a movie with a truly unique plot line. Most are just the same ideas over and over again, just projected differently. I found this movie, and the first, to be quite refreshing. Something new, exciting, and thought provoking. The idea that the bad guy doesn't actually kill his victims himself, and his motive behind the torcher is something to make anyone stop and think. Left open for a trilogy, which I always like anticipation. I'd like to Amanda mess something up in the next one and be killed and finally end the jigsaw killings, but who knows. We'll just have to wait and see. Overall, very good movie, camera shots and angles made me a little queasy, but well written. it's a breathe of fresh air.

title: If you enjoyed this film, please turn yourself in
review:
Really, if you enjoyed this film, you should call the police and turn yourself in, because you are one sick puppy.

This movie is beyond depraved - it's a new nadir in American film-making. I understand why the producers made this film - they were trying to get rich, and they did. But their children won't be seeing this film anytime soon, and neither should yours. Nor should you, for that matter. It has no redeeming value. If you're deep into gore, just go watch one of the original Living Dead movies. They're actually better films, and less dehumanizing. At least the zombies there are killing for food. Bad acting, bad writing, absurd killing machines, little real action, no real tension, and no cognizable plot. Avoid.

title: gruesome and unpleasant
review: Contemptible sequel to the 2004 surprise hit is nothing more than an endless barrage of unappealing characters, excessive cruelty, and relentless violence. This time around the mysterious "killer" known as Jigsaw locks horns with a hotheaded cop (Wahlberg) whose shady resume endangers the life of his teenage son, as well as several other strangers who have the misfortune of unknowingly being linked to him. The result is a lazy exercise in slasher film noir, as we get yet another movie where people run around screaming, arguing, and getting "offed" one by one. Story is contrived, the suspense nonexistent, and a giant plot twist just comes off as a cheap trick. May please the right audience, but there isn't anything or anyone to care about in the movie. *½

title: A simply perfect film..nicer than the first
review: This film is totally awesome. I like the connections between the people involved. I liked the different characters, all characterized with something, and i liked the plan presented by john the 'jigsaw' and Amanda. But most of all, i liked the possible inclusion of Dr.Gordon which may result in his survival(the first scene where we see the guy watching the tape when during surgery he had a key put in his eye...assuming that the 'jigsaw couldn't do surgery and the guy performing it was limping which makes us viewers think he could be Dr.Gordon. Every detail gives an explanation to something. I recommend this film to those who love psychological thrillers.

title: Same experience as the original
review:
Okay, people for those of you who are particularly familiar with recent horror movies I think we can all agree that one of the best ones to catch our eyes in recent years will be Saw. Considering the decline of horror movies in recent years its refreshing to see a new idea thrown on the table that breathes new life into a dying genre. What worries me is the way it does so. What Saw basically did was take up the violence level and take it up three notches. One more notch and you'd be watching a snuff film. Now truthfully I think we should all be worried about the fact that audiences are becoming so desensitized that filmmakers have to become more brutal to get any impact.

Now I'm not here to blam Saw, lord knows it is still a favourite movie of mine. If Saw didn't incorporate a good story with some good twists and some good characters in its mix of blood and pain, I would give it the biggest blam ever. Thank god it does have all of the above, thus making Saw one of the better if not best horror movies of recent years.

But does the sequel live up to the first one? Again I'm thankful to say it does.

Usually the word "sequel" is enough to put fear into the hearts of many film buffs. I'm still trying to get over the disappointment of Matrix Reloaded which in the matter of 3 hours killed of my 4 year love of the Matrix, not to mention I still cringe when I hear "Jeepers Creepers 2" *cringes*.

Saw 2 gladly lives up to the hype and the expectation of Saw. I can't say it is at all an improvement but what you are looking at is more of the same. Everything from the gritty atmosphere, to the downright macabre deaths, to the twists and turns in the plot are those that you would expect from the original.

I'm too tired to keep writing this review all I can say is that, this is one movie that lives to its hype. On the downside some of the acting sucks, but you'd be so caught up in the gruesome and unrelenting action that there's a good chance you wont care too much.

title: Amazing. Better than the First
review:
Besides amazing, I'm not sure how to explain this masterpiece. If you have seen the first Saw, you know that it just throws itself into the film and there isn't that much story. Well, the second film also throws itself into the gore, but actually evolves into a great story that also shows us a little about Jigsaws past. We learn why Jigsaw (John) does what he does, allows people to play games of life that usually end for the worse.

Saw 2 isn't necessarily gorier that the first, but there are a few scenes that make you cringe at the sight of it (namely the needle pit). The ending to this film goes down as one of the best endings ever in cinematic history. It leaves it open for a third Saw that I can't wait for (due out October 27, 2006). On a side note, the DVD to SAW 2 is out February 14, 2006, definitely go buy this masterpiece.

title: My Thumb is Up.
review:
I watched Saw II a while ago, but I never got around to putting my two cents until now.

I rented the first Saw film, and I have to say that I really enjoyed it. REALLY enjoyed it. Especially compared to other horror films, it was very good-It not only put people in frightening situations, which is what horror movies have to do, but also made the audience think. It stayed away from "cheap scares," and instead went for raw suspense.

The second one, however, was just as good. I had no idea what to think going into it, but I knew that it would either be a very good sequel or a very bad sequel-it just had that sort of vibe about it.

I was thrilled to find that it was the former.

Many people have watched the movie and spent too much time thinking about the gore to realize that this movie actually is an intelligent one. Yes, they see that Jigsaw is one smart cookie even while being completely bonkers, but they don't see that the movie itself is very smart.

Far too many viewers see the house and immediately jump to the conclusion that the people in it are the main characters. The main characters in this film are Mathews and Jigsaw. Period. The characters in the house are merely props for the big idea, which is the "game" that Mathews is playing. In the first movie, Adam and Laurence were the main characters playing their game. The other victims seemed to be only for background, but they proved to be important in their own light. The same thing goes for the second, but the other victims are more emphasized. If you think that the house guests are the main characters after watching the movie, you need to watch it again.

The movie's twists were all very intriguing, even while Amanda being in on it all seemed a bit far-fetched.

Finally, a lot of people speak badly of the violence. Yes, this movie is very gory. Seemingly gratuitous at times. The fact is, however, gore is edgy. Edgy is suspenseful. Suspenseful is thrilling. This movie is a thriller. Get over it.

Well...that's all I have to say. If you disagree, well, that's none of my business anyway.

title: The tag line boasts, 'Oh yes, there will be blood,' and oh yes, there was
review:
Saw II

Directed by Darren Lynn Bousman.

Starring Donnie Wahlberg, Shawnee Smith and Tobin Bell.

With a troubled son, a pending divorce, and a serial killer who asks for him by name, Detective Eric Mathews (Wahlberg, "Band of Brothers", "Dreamcatcher") is having a rough time. Matters only worsen when the aforementioned serial killer (a frighteningly matter-of-fact Tobin Bell) begins his new "game." The murderer, dubbed Jigsaw by the media, sticks several ex-con stereotypes in a booby-trapped house and watches the chaos ensue from his hideout. Mathews discovers Jigsaw's lair, and takes his team to bring the maniac to justice. When the detective discovers his son is one of the unlucky few inside the house, the case becomes a blurred line between Mathews' personal and professional interests.

With the departure of director James Wan (who helmed the first film), Darren Lynn Bousman, a relative unknown, fastens himself into the blood-encrusted shackles. Bousman does not stray far from the formula used by Wan in the original: quick cuts in times of panic, dizzying camera angles, overall confusion.

The tag line boasts, "Oh yes, there will be blood," and oh yes, there was. "Saw II" requires from its viewers a high tolerance of gore. Knowing that no one can argue that it is a tame affair, the filmmakers try a little too hard to make "Saw II" more than it is. Much like "Saw", the film tries to cram as much guts as it can fit down the audiences' throats while also leaving them with something to think about when the credits begin to roll. Do Jigsaw's subjects deserve to live if they cannot make the necessary sacrifices? Does Detective Mathews' history of police brutality justify his son's torment? These are interesting questions, but are ultimately irrelevant. The filmmakers are more concerned with burning people alive or having them crawl through hypodermic needles than focusing on why any of it happens at all.

"Saw II" is an above average horror movie, at best. It is memorable only to the fans that can stomach the blood and guts genre that is horror. It'll certainly keep audiences on the edge of their seat, but in the end it falls in line with typical frightful fare. Most enjoyable to watch with friends late at night, just make sure you don't have to walk home alone.

Final Grade: C+

title: good film yet some plot holes
review:
After seeing 'Saw 2' (2005) I came out from the cinema thinking it was the best horror movie I had ever seen. It contained everything I liked about the horror genre in it; scary psycho killer, psychological horror, riddles and of course a major twist at the end.

However I did find that a lot of the riddles in the film I had already guessed the answer to, which was probably because I had seen the first 'Saw' so was expecting them.

This leads me to believe that there possibly should not have been a sequel. It was a very good plot and I did think it was worth seeing, but it wasn't as fast paced as I would have expected it to be or liked it to be.

I thought the acting was exceptional and the camera angles throughout really helped to emphasise the horror. This was best shown when the girl fell in the pit of needles it went to an aerial view, which showed her expression, and her body surrounded by the needles.

Unfortunately I did notice a few plot holes. How did Xavier know which order to put the number combination in the safe? And the fact that Obi gets the syringe from the oven for someone else should have let him out as he has done his 'penance' by not being selfish yet he still burned alive?

Perhaps I am just thinking about it too much as the friend who I saw it with did not notice these. Judging from her reaction at some parts in during the film I can safely say it achieved a scream. until 'Saw 2' i had never bothered to look around at the audience but its actually really interesting looking at how people react. The most effective scenes at getting a reaction were those which preyed on people's general fears, such as needles and fire and lots of blood, especially when it slowly dribbled down someone's arms.

In conclusion I did feel that this was a great horror film yet it had too much to live up to as the first 'Saw' was so shocking. The shock effect and the art of the riddles did not impress a second time round.

title: Those who do not appreciate life, do not deserve life
review:
'Saw' is one of those movies that makes you want to run off and jot down a plot for your own Horror/Thriller story. The thriller factor is exceeded only by the originality and that feeling of 'what-will-happen-next?' This movie will keep you guessing until the very end, where the final twists unfold and will truly make your jaw drop.

'Saw' and 'Saw 2' are based around mental torture games performed by a serial killer known as Jigsaw. Jigsaw is not as sick as he is made out to be, though, as these torturous games are targeted at people who take life for granted. In the first of the 2 films, two men are chained to pipes in a bathroom in a seemingly empty lair. Between them is a dead body, and they have to find clues and go to hell and back to figure out how to get the hell out of there. What happens in the end? Well, if you are wondering that, why in the hell are you already looking at the sequel!

Saw 2 is more gruesome and mysterious than ever, with a whole bunch of new victims in the palm of Jigsaw's hand. Well, not exactly all are new, a victim from the first Saw is part of the group also, and is familiar with what is happening. But not everything is what it seems in this fantastic sequel to the thriller that is 'Saw', want to find out? You'd better see it quickly, and remember, those who do not appreciate life, do not deserve life.
