Also Jigsaw is a complete hypocrite since he doesn't appreciate his own life by spending the last few years he has left making others' a misery. For whatever reason the traps were too hard to solve in time so instead of being an obstacle to overcome and appreciate & possibly from his angle gain living disciples in recognition for being a good teacher, he fails again by giving the victims self destructive alternatives to save their life. It just made me apathetic watching it as there wasn't any wins to motivate any of them to try & survive like in the movie "Cube". I didn't like how the Detective Mathews leaves Jigsaw in the car still alive whilst he goes off to be trapped like "the Vanishing". That was so obvious that was going to happen. I did however like how the cops allowed Detective Mathews to beat up on Jigsaw to get answers which is how we should treat these animals. Give them a taste of their own medicine. They don't seem to like that.

title: Not as good as the original, but still a fun time
review:
I enjoyed the original Saw for its ability to build an atmosphere of discomfort and hold it for the length of the film. It was creative and disturbing and just a really fun horror film, and Jigsaw -- the villain -- was one of the most refreshing horror villains to come along in a long time.

Saw II does not quite live up to its predecessor in that it leaves too many plot holes and -- for the most part -- ends up resorting to having its characters just walk around endlessly for much of the film. Certain characters seem to hold no purpose and some questions are left completely unanswered, such as the motivations of some of the victims locked in the house by Jigsaw.

As well, some of the traps set up in the house are so obvious that the effectiveness fails. You are left in the same position as most bad horror films where you ask yourself of the main characters, "Why are they doing that?"

However, even with all of these shortcomings, the film is a fun little picture to watch. Like the original, the setup of the film is unique and thus it is nice to see something in a horror film that is more than just more of the same. As with the first film, there is a twist at the end of this one that was very impressively pulled off. I probably wouldn't recommend this as a must-see in the theatres, but it is easily something th

title: A Nutshell Review: Saw II
review:
I'm such a fan of the original - I like blood and gore, and Saw had one of the more intriguing and sick stories around, which saw the introduction of an original villain in recent memory, Jigsaw. What worked in the first film was the strange premise of 2 seemingly unrelated characters being put in a life and death situation, forced to compromise or die together. Also, the twist at the end was oh-so-nicely done, that it just begs for a sequel to be made.

But I was initially skeptical at how a sequel could top the original Saw. Sure, Jigsaw returns, but are we expecting more of his sick games to beef up the sequel, leading it predictably to more of the same? Surprisingly, it doesn't. Now, you have a group of 8 persons stuck in an unknown booby-trapped building in which they have to escape from. Needless to say, Jigsaw has the entire plan rigged right from the beginning, except that the audience and the players don't know how, or why. It's reasonable to say that you'll be expecting characters to die one-by-one, in bloody manner (so promised the tagline) befitting the original.

While Jigsaw was mostly heard and not seen in the first movie, here, he's seen and heard in full glory. Donnie Wahlberg plays detective Eric Matthews, who leads his partner Kerry (Dina Meyer) and a group of SWAT to take down Jigsaw. Playing a psychological game with Eric, Jigsaw taunts him while explaining to the audience a little bit of his own background, which tied to elements from Saw.

Fans of the original will squeal with delight when these tiebacks, settings and even a character make an appearance in the sequel. It links the two movies together very nicely, and I wonder why the local distributors didn't have a back to back screening this time, like what they did for Kill Bill.

Alas, the version shown here, despite its NC-16 rating, is a watered down version. Obtaining a decent box office returns would have ruled out the M18 or R21 cut. However, don't let this minor nitty gritty spoil your fun.

At times, this movie hums along and you find predictable elements (at least I thought it was under threat of becoming a so-so mediocre sequel), but the last 10 minutes will leave you at the edge of your seat, and deliver when you least expected it, applying a signature that says "Yes, this is a Saw movie". Another sequel, if there is any, will be in my list of must-watch.

title: This movie does not teach anyone the value of life
review: I'll begin my comment with a bias of mine--I am biased against a movie that leaves a disgusting, grimy feeling on me when I head toward my car having seen it. I'm no movie buff, but I consider a movie good if it consists of various elements of entertainment. A good plot, mixed with some light and heavy moments, depending on what sort of movie it is. Likable characters--always a plus. Overall, a balance which is hard to describe yet easy to recognize. So when I see a movie with no clear protagonist, not one moment of levity, and despicable characters all around, I'm apt to dislike it. The aim of this movie was to invoke two hours of uneasiness and revulsion. I'd say the entertainment value of this movie would be equivalent to staring at fatal accident victims or beheading videos. But at least there's some feeling of separation when it comes to the latter. Movies are different. They're designed to immerse its audience. Big Fish, now that's a great movie. Anyway, my point is give me something to work with, something I can use. Not two hours of filth. To the movie's credit however it did achieve it's aim. It did invoke tension. But where is the release? I suppose the release is when you realize it was just a movie. Now, you see, I hate that. If I'm going to experience something, I would at least like to take something positive out of it. The only positive part was narrowing in on what I don't like. And the cliché of appreciating life. Make every moment count. Not making every moment count is a part of life. Should people be, "Oh my God, I'm going to die at this specific time. What do I do? I'm so scared!" Or should people rather be, "I now know I have two hours to live. I'd rather spend the next two hours calm and collected and then move on to what's next." And anyway, Carpe diem means "pluck the day" not "seize" it. Make the best of opportunities given to you, not go on this ridiculous and constant high. Perhaps part of appreciating life is knowing when not to take it so seriously, because once you start taking life so seriously all the time, it ceases to become your life but contingent on ultimately useless and extraneous parts of a relative reality, which is the message this movie pushes. If someone really wishes to teach people to appreciate life, a good place to start is to teach them to appreciate death. That's the amazing part. Out of all the billions of lifeforms there are, you're just one of them, and like all the rest, you're part of the same cycle. And to just start there and listen to how quiet it is is more enlightening than any Hollywood pedagogy, especially the specious dogma Saw II prattles. And that's why I dislike Saw II and would not recommend it.

title: Saw II--Good, or bad?
review:
I don't know exactly how I felt about Saw II. The ending was a little bit confusing for me. Although I don't want to give away anything, the ending seemed to me like it didn't exactly fit together with the rest of the movie. Parts of it did, but there were also parts where I sat there thinking, "What? There's no way in hell that could've happened." If you've seen Saw I, and if you're looking at this, I'm sure you have, you know that "Jigsaw" is the old man with cancer at the beginning of the movie. How does an elderly man that's dying pull all that off? It's not probable, but then again, I don't really think anyone could pull that off with absolutely no flaws.

The 1st one was definitely a lot better, but what do you expect, right? With a movie like that, it's almost predictable that they will make a second one, but stupid at the same time, because you know by even looking at the previews that it's not going to be as good.

Anddddd, judging by the ending of the second one, I'm almost sure that they're going to make a 3rd one. I'd recommend renting the 3rd and 2nd ones, because the second one is almost a waste of 9 dollars, and the 3rd one I can almost guarantee will be a waste.

Saw II will keep you thinking though. Not that the 1st one didn't. But, hey, if you like that sort of thing, I'd recommend seeing it.

title: The Best Movie in a LONG TIME!

title: Nothing like its original
review:
Eight people, several rooms and again the incapable police. Jigsaw again came out with a plan and this time he decided to put eight people into a house with several doors (or so-to-say rooms). One of these strangers is to us well-known Amanda, who was the only one to survive Jigsaw's trap. Eventually they find out that they are all connected to each other somehow  they were all arrested by Det. Eric Matthews (played by Donnie Wahlberg), with the exception of Daniel who was his son.

On the other end we have E. Matthews and S.W.A.T. who broke into Jigsaw's place. Jigsaw, or as he introduced himself as John, wanted to talk to Matthews alone. On his opinion, he doesn't appreciate his son's life, so I guess that's the reason enough to threat Daniel's life. Anyways, John has changed so much since the last time we saw him in Saw, his face just wasn't the same, it was poor, it grew thin. Now I know that he has a cancer but I wouldn't say that they changed a person so much only because of that to shoot a movie. We can even see in flash-back, when he went to the doctor to find out that he was dying, he looked the same as in Saw II, not as in Saw. Now that's strange. And it just didn't seem believable that such an old man with a cancer, barely breathing, barely moving, would be able to come out with and "direct" such a brilliant game.

Well, back to those eight people who were reducing themselves one by one. The point of the game was as usual, to stay alive. Their task was to find an antidote (they were breathing in a deadly nerve agent) as soon as possible  they've gotten only 2 hours left.

In the mean time, Det. E. Matthews has almost beaten Jigsaw to death. Yes, good work, that's the way the police works. And again Jigsaw tricked them, again he was smarter than them  he won again. Matthews imposed upon the things that Jigsaw said, he was led into a wrong house by Jigsaw. He was looking for his son but has found himself in the wrong place. The whole time Daniel was there in the Jigsaw's place. This Jigsaw really likes to play games till the end  with cops too. And those tape-recordings that we see playing on computers in his room  they weren't even live. Kind of predictable, when he says to Det. Matthews not to worry about his son, that he's in a safe and secure state. John tricked the police again but this time he wasn't alone. He had a little helper, someone who was a former drug-addict. Oh, yes, his helper was Amanda herself. John has been her teacher and he's been giving her lessons of so-called life and appreciations of life. And since he's been dying, Amanda decided to carry on his work.

I must admit I knew about the ending all along because it was a rumor since the beginning. But even if I didn't know that, I wouldn't consider that being a twist. They so wanted to approach this movie to its original that they failed in inventing something new and so they've really moved from what Saw represented.

This movie lacks James Wan (the director of Saw) and of course Leigh Whannell as an actor (co-writer of screenplay). It basically lacks all the benefits that movie Saw had. I'd give a movie 7 stars because I can't just overlook Jigsaw's amazing and well-directed game.

7/10

title: Not like the first one
review: Well, I'm sorry to say that Saw II is NOT as good as Saw. I'll get right to the point. There were definitely some gory and frightening situations/"games" in this one, and they definitely made you cringe. Also, John/Jigsaw was played great. His character was the best thing about the movie. He's a real sinister, twisted guy, but he's one of those villains who's just so good at what he does that it's awesome. But the goods stop there. First off, the cast was terrible in this one (except for Jigsaw, of course). Very few of the actors could really act or make their characters convincing at all. I ESPECIALLY hate that big bulky guy Xavier. That character was one of the biggest morons in a horror movie that I've ever seen. Jigsaw is such a clever, crafty killer, he would have never picked such a clumsy fool for a victim like this guy. Xavier is no match for Jigsaw in the slightest bit, and you'd like to think Jigsaw would have found watching this guy completely boring. There's NO way this guy could survive Jigsaw's genius. Two, the elaborate and huge games in this one were totally unreal. I mean you'd have to have a legion of murdering psychopaths to pull off the stuff Jigsaw was doing in this one. That was kind of ridiculous. Finally, the twist at the end was AWFUL. Not looking forward to Saw III at all. Sorry guys. This one's just not that great. Okay, but not that great.

title: Pretty predictable...but better than the first
review:
I am not a big fan of the Saw series, so if you loved the first, you might as well stop reading...because it sucked. I will give it kudos for improving from the first Saw - the acting was better and plot holes and mistakes in the filming were harder to come by.

The gore in this movie was nothing spectacular, in fact it was substandard . The camera was seizure inducing and erratic, detracting from the grossness. Half of the time it was hard to understand what was going on.

Now to the story where the movie falls apart. This is quite possibly one of the most predictable movies I have seen. I was able to guess correctly about 80% of the movie within the first half hour to forty five minutes - which was really disappointing. The characters miss huge clues given to them by "Jigsaw" and it is often infuriating to watch their stupidity.

I advise to wait until the movie comes out on DVD so you don't have to sell your kidneys to pay for a movie ticket - because its not that great.

title: Good, grisly fun
review:
Jigsaw (Tobin Bell ) is a psycho who makes good on his promise - "There will be blood." If inventive sadism is your idea of a fun night at the movies, "Saw II" delivers ninety minutes of relentless screw-tightening shocks.

In spite of its nonsensical conclusion James Wan's "Saw" was a engagingly grisly, brutally graphic thrill ride that delivered box office gold. With a twenty-five day shooting schedule forcing inventiveness and a tad more logic thrown into the mix, "Saw II" is a rarity among sequels: it's as good as the original. Instead of two characters and a corpse, we now have eight tortured victims united by one common bond.

Bad cop Mark Wahlberg can't seem to reign in his teenage son (Frankie Munoz substitute Erik Knudsen) who seems well on his way to a guest spot on "America's Most Wanted." That's all the impetus Jigsaw, a scientist when it comes to preying upon the weakness of his victims, needs to set the sequel's mechanics in motion. "Saw II' plays a clever twist on the original by placing the hero and villain, instead of the two victims, in one room. With a handful of TV monitors broadcasting closed-circuit coverage of the action, Jigsaw delights in watching the detective squirm.

The gut-churning parade kicks off with a pre-credit sequence in which the key to freedom is surgically implanted in the eye of it's victim. Two choices: either pull a Bunuel and slice wide your retina or suffer the fate of a Mario Bava-inspired spiked black mask timed to turn its victim's head into a colander. A pit of hypodermic needles, gallons of coughed-up blood and thoughts on serial killers and their quest for immortality suggest a game of "Clue" gone terribly wrong.

Casting "Saw's" Shawnee Smith, the only survivor of Jigsaw's game, in a key role proves that a sequel was never far from the mind of the franchise's creator. Instead of limiting the gore to one room, "Saw II' gives us an entire tenement in which to splatter about. Nerve gas, the film references the terrorist attacks on the Tokyo subway, is being pumped into the vents and Jigsawagrees to unlock the door one hour after the poison takes full effect.

With the exception of Tobin Bell, the rest of the actors were cast according to type. As the soft-spoken ringleader of carnage, Bell provides the prerequisite of every good horror yarn: a truly despicable antagonist. Quiet revelations of his gut-shot illness will have you cheering on the cancer.

It should come as no surprise that only a few characters live to see the final fade out and credit the filmmakers with devising several new sado-masochistic kinks. Not content to simply rearrange the narrative order of its predecessor, "Saw II" will not disappoint fans of the original.

title: My two cents...(possible spoilers)
review:
When I watched Saw 2 I found a few problems with it. Overall it was an alright movie, I give it 6/10, however I did find the ending very good. I kind of knew this would be a "teen slasher" type movie and I was kinda right.

In the first Saw, it was so great because the main focus was on just two guys, and because most of the movie focuses on them, you got to learn lot about them both and see how the characters develop. In Saw 2 I barely know anything about the characters, one guy gets killed after he says about 3 lines. In the first Saw it was SO much more captivating, with both the story of the two guys in the room, the detectives on the outside world, and flashbacks, it created a bloody awesome movie, and thats why its my favorite.

Also in Saw 2, there were only about 3 cool deaths, the guy at the start,Obiin the furnace, and the chick with her wrists, the rest were either a guy killing another guy or something else.

Not enough happened in this movie, most of it was just the people trying to find a way out of the house. A lot of the time they were all intoxicated by the nerve gas and were stumbling around like idiots.

They should never have made this movie, the first Saw was brilliant in ever way and I give it 10/10, but making a sequel was poor especially with the simple idea of just having people in a house, getting killed in traps.

The fact that Saw was made by Leigh Whanell and James Wan, who are both Melbourne, Australia blokes, means a lot to me, as Melbourne is my home and to have such a damn awesome film come from them is awesome, especially with Australian talent just starting to emerge.

Saw 2 - basically not enough story line, not enough character development, not enough cool deaths and was not very scary in a psychological way, as was the first one.

Please give me your feedback on your opinions :)

title: Nowhere near as good as the original
review:
I wasn't expecting much from this, but that was a good thing as it didn't do much to prove me otherwise. It's an okay movie, but just nowhere near as clever or original as its predecessor.

Go to see it expecting anything other than "House on Haunted Hill" with the killer from "Saw", with lots of blood and you'll be disappointed.

I can't even remember who the main character who played the cop was now, and I only saw the move on Saturday. It wasn't a particularly memorable performance, nor was it a bad performance. Like much of the movie then; just treading water till the credits are up along with the inevitable open door for another sequel...

title: Stupid Victim Tricks...where's Letterman when you need him?
review: While SmartTALX was a tad harsh in his assessment, it's still valid. But more importantly it is the whispered fragments of dialog that "John" or "Jigsaw" gives that do add some feature redeeming quality to this film. His flashbacks to the knowledge of his impending death, and the savor it adds to life, and the instinct of survival that he notes is lost amongst the common man. All of these fragments DO make a cohesive whole. I can say, without spoiling anything, that there is an opportunity for a "Saw 3". If some of the plot work tightens up, as SmartTALX suggest, with some fleshing out of this 'motivation' that John has this franchise will make the 3rd installment the best. It's well worth watching, for the essence of survival it hints at, not for the mechanistic methods of DEATH Jigsaw engineers for the violent prurience of the baser viewer.

Unfortunately though, the movie constantly seemed like it was trying too hard to live up to it's prequel. It wasn't as creative, as suspenseful or as shocking. Every twist and turn seemed mediocre at best. Although, that may be unfair since everyone who had seen Saw I had already been exposed to all of these gruesome and horrific plot twists, and it is of course extremely difficult to top that.

I went into this movie expecting to be scared out of my mind seeing as how after the first one I couldn't sleep without my light on for weeks after. title: Oh Yes There Is Blood...Lot's and Lots of Blood
review: Saw II is not a movie for everyone. I mean you have to really like horror films to enjoy this flick. Hell even die hard horror fans might not like it because unlike the usual low budget horror films with a deformed man under a mask who doesn't speak at all, moves at a snail's pace and still manages to catch up to his victims, Saw II is a thinking man's horror film and I know horror fans hate to think. Saw II is a rarity. It's a sequel that is not better than the original but damn good. i think what makes these films so good is the originality in the serial killer Jigsaw (Tobin Bell). Jigsaw isn't a larger than life superhuman deformed man behind a mask. He's a cancer patient that kidnaps his victims and plays games with them. Unlike Jason Voorhees, Freddy Kruger, Michael Myers, Leatherface and Pinhead Jigsaw gives his victims a chance at survival, although it's a slimmer than slim chance. Jigsaw picks the scum of society for his victims. Drug dealers, drug addicts, hookers, etc., etc. basically people that society wouldn't miss. These are people that have done wrong in life and Jigsaw wants to show them the error of their ways. Of course this doesn't mean that what he does is justified, it's just what makes him different. Unlike the first film which had two victims Saw II has five kidnappee's all locked in an abandoned house. One of the victims is a kid named Daniel (Eric Knudsen) who is the son of police detective Eric Matthews (Cambridge's own Donnie Wahalberg, yes the same Wahlberg who is the older brother of Mark and danced on stage as a member of New Kids On The Block). Now Det. Matthews has two hours to save his son who has been notified via a cassette player, as all Jigsaw's victims, that the captives have been breathing in a deadly nerve toxin. However somewhere in the house they are being held in is the antidote. If they can find the antidote they will be alive when the doors open in three hours. if they can't they'll all be dead in two. Now Det. Matthews has to work one on one with Jigsaw or he never see's his delinquent son alive again. Saw II is creepy on a level unlike most slasher films, it could happen. There is a ton of sick people in this world and if someone like this Jigsaw guy exits I'm glad I don't know about it. Saw II like the first one had a twist I never saw coming, which is what I like about it. The victims are your typical victims. There's the sensible one Jonas (Glenn Plummer), the innocent one Laura (Beverly Mitchell), the annoying one Addison (Emmanuelle Vaugier), the expert Amanda (Shawnee Smith) and the jerk who you can't wait to see bumped off Xavier (Fraky G, I hate when actors use dumb names like that) plus the Detective's son Daniel. However the typical horror victims aside Saw II is great. If you like horror films and are begging for something different, something the genre has only done with House Of 1,000 Corpses, The Devils Rejects, The Texas Chainsaw Massacre remake (yes I thought the remake blew the original away, I mean how is the original so scary when you can't even see it because there is no lighting people!!!)then I highly recommend Saw II. If you haven't seen Saw then rent it first. Like the first one Saw II is the perfect hybrid of A Nightmare On Elm Street and Silence Of The Lambs. As I said before this film is not for everyone. It is graphically violent. After all what would you expect from a film that's tag line is "Oh Yes, There Will Be Blood" and has a poster that has two rotted fingers that make the roman numeral for II. On a scale of ten I give Saw II an 8. The original gets a 10. I saw this film with my wife and best friend and both my friend and I loved it while my wife didn't care for it. So there's two opinions in one review.

title: very entertaining
review: This movie rocks! Definantley better than the first. The story line was awesome and the characters were interesting. I definitely recommend this movie to anyone seeking a thrill. Just make sure that you watch it with some one that will enjoy watching you jump and squirm because they will get a laugh out of it.

title: Listen very closely.
review: Very very seldom does a sequel ever shine as bright as Saw 2. Very seldom does a sequel go above and beyond its other half... but Saw 2 does all of this. Fans of the first rejoice because Saw 2 does compare and sometimes outshines one of the most under-your-skin movies of our time. The blood has been kicked up a couple notches and some of the traps are even more harrowing than the last (i.e. the death mask or the Chinese "blade" trap). The movie starts as a kick in the pants (just like the first) and makes certain you're aware that the games are not over. The beginning can be a little slow for those who just want blood and gore, but I was able to stomach it. It's actually kind of necessary once you get a grasp on the story. Once we skip ahead to the house that the players are trapped in, the movie kicks into high gear. Slowly the characters are dying because of the nerve gas they breath in and, this in turn, blurs their sense of reasoning and, often times, logical decision making. The ending is not what I expected and that's a good thing. After the movie was over I knew I got my $8 worth. I highly recommend this to people who know what good movies are. I've read some paper reviews on this, and clearly those people don't know what a "movie" is. If you haven't watched the first Saw, don't worry. You can still enjoy this one with little or no previous knowledge of the first movie. If you have seen the first Saw then clearly you rock. Just heed my advice before watching: listen very closely.

title: It's a damn worthy sequel!
review:
I'd have to say that this is one of the best sequels in years! Once, I had seen Saw (I), I knew that there was going to be a sequel and I was waiting patiently ever since. I first figured, how could a person other than James Wan, the director and script writer of the original, write a worthy sequel. Well, one succeeded, need I say more! The plot is a lot more deep than the original, especially because you really get to know Jigsaw now! It's also packed with very inventive and stupendously harsh kills, again need I say more. The ending, which I can't say of course is again brilliant, but makes me wonder if Saw III, because we know that's coming, will be any good, again need I say more.

They've done an astonishing job in 25 days, I believe it was 25, and made it the best low-budget sequel ever!, KUDOS! Need I say more, oh yes, there will be blood....

title: one of the best sequel ever
review:
The story have well been twisted... as expected. This is the best thriller sequel ever.

It's not like if they take you to a complete other climax or situation, it's the same we know but with a different point of you. This film is splendid.

You have to see it even if you dislike the first because it's not like any other suspense thriller ''Ã -la Final Destination'' that count only on more gore, more loud, more we don't wanna know things. title: How bout that ending...?
review: Wow...I just saw Saw 2 last night after being directed to do such by a few friends, and I must say....I WAS impressed. Don't go into the theater expecting to see a classic, because, well...it IS a horror movie. But if you liked the first one, by all means, Definitely go and see this one. I enjoyed the first one a lot, but more than anything else, I loved the ending, as I do with any movie with a crazy twist at the end. Never would I in a million years would I have guessed that they could make an ending just as amazing, but on a whole new level...I don't know, and many night not agree with me here, but I think we definitely have some new talent on the market of horror directors/writers/etc here. Its hard to really compare to the older horror classics, because, well, for lack of a better way to say it, It's not one....But I think you'd be hard pressed to find a movie of this type that even gives Saw 2 a SLIGHT run for it's money....!

title: Nothing special, trust me
review:
Seriously, I don't know how this has got a vote average above 7, I would think it over-rated at much above 5.

The key question to ask yourself here is "Have I seen Cube?" If you have, don't bother with this - it's got a similar approach with the selection of death-traps to be out-witted or avoided but these are inferior to those in Cube and the characters are significantly more stupid in their approach. If you haven't, don't bother with this - go and watch Cube which does a similar job with a lot more style and creativity.

How creative you view the deaths as here and how you view the "I'm testing people's strength of character, will to survive, making them live" speeches of the gimp running it all will depend entirely on your previous experience of horror (especially psychological horror) films. If you've seen a few, this will not rate highly on your list.

Stupid, illogical characters, pointless aggression and swearing, a tiresome "philosophical" villain (he keeps talking about how people don't value their lives and if they don't, don't deserve to live, but himself didn't appreciate his own until... well, wouldn't want to spoil it, but it makes him hypocritically stupid. And not just in a "he's a flawed person" type way, in a "god this is stupid" way).

I saw it with 2 other people experienced in watching horror films of all kinds, and not one of us had any more reaction than a shrug of the shoulders and "that was a waste of cash". I'm not so hardened that some films don't get to me but this one... Not one death or piece of action disturbed, upset, moved or excited me. There was nothing really clever in it or thought provoking (which is what they seemed to be pressing for with the old guy) or to leave you somehow "cold" or "open-mouthed" which is what they were also blatantly pushing for with the "Usual Suspects" or "Unbreakable" type method of detailing the "twist" ending. The twist is nothing to get excited about really. It's the only genuinely quite clever part of the film, but the final, final part... It isn't really anything more than a cheap set-up for a sequel.

Final point of note: Possibly one of the key flaws of the whole atmosphere This is one of those films done with so much use of filter, quick cuts, overly-stylised angles, etc that nothing feels "real". There is a feeling of detachment created which keeps the whole thing remote and destroys a lot of the potential for getting you to feel like you're there or there's any sort of organic realness to what's happening.

Don't waste your time or money on this.

title: SAW 2 director in need of help!!
review:
I believe that the director for SAW2 did not give us that edgy shock that was delivered in SAW. Although I feel a little disappointed with the fact that I had worked out the plot half way through the film, I still enjoyed a few edgy moments here and there..

Clever cinematography.. acting was a little bit dry; we should of had a bit more intensity with the character building..

I feel cheated of mainly because I was expecting a lot more of that shock factor that SAW brought to us last year. There were twists and twirls through the film but there seemed to be nothing more than a predictable few.

The gore and bloodshed was at an extreme level which was mostly expected of!

All in all.. worth watching..

title: Great but not as much as the first Saw
review: I watched this movie yesterday evening and I was hoping for a sequel as good as the first Saw. In fact, the story is quite good but as a whole Saw was more frightening. Yes there is blood, a lot of it, yes you jump from your seat from time to time but yet I was disappointed. One thing that is the same as in Saw is the fact there are a lot of sudden new developments which is great. Actors play well and I even had the surprise to discover Beverly Mitchell among them :-) So if you haven't seen this movie yet, I'm a bit doubtful about whether you should see it or not. The best thing to do would be to go and watch the film and make your own opinion ;-) 7/10

title: may be as good as original saw
review: I saw this movie the first day it came out and was pretty surprised to see the cinema packed. Not in my life of going to cinema, I have seen cinema hall ever that full of people. After watching the movie, I had a big problem trying to analyze if it was better than the first saw or not. The conclusion I came up with is that it might be, depending on the kind of movies you personally like. I like movies with great deal of twist right at the end of the movie. Even though both the saws manage to deliver that twist in the end, I thought the twist in saw was really fascinating. Anyway, a great movie to watch and definitely worth spending your money and time.

title: Arguable the best horror film thus far this year
review: For me, movies like Saw II are hard to come by for me. Those movies that keep you up at night just trying to pick apart the plot and create your own answers. Saw II begins with a group of individuals inside a rigged house complete with gas, guns, and gory gadgets. Eric Matthews feels that the fate of the entire household is in his hands. As the movie progressed, my mind was fixed on one speculation...but when the ending came, It spun it upside down, punched it in the face, and threw it back at me. Although the movie is very gory, I think the plot and excellent acting (especially on Tobin Bell's part) makes up for it. Highly Reccomeneded if you're into plot twists and mind boggling.

title: A Killer Horror Sequel
review:
After a bloody aftermath in the original, Tobin Bell returns as the sick and twisted Jigsaw serial killer. This time, the number of unlucky victims is now four times as many. The Jigsaw wants to teach them the value of life. When the game begins and the traps are set, that's when they realize how badly they want to survive the horror.

The story revolves around with this cop, Eric Matthews, who is in pursuit of the killer alongside with Detective Kerry who reprises her role from the first one. With the hint given from the teaser scene, Eric catches a break and finds a lead to Jigsaw's whereabout. Everyone rushes to his hideout and there, they find the video feed of the booby trapped shelter. Eric Matthews gets filled with anger when he sees his son included in the game of hunt for survival. Meanwhile, the victims are locked in a room while slowly dying from a lethal nerve gas. The victims are able to walk around freely in the house unlike the players in the first one who were chained and almost had zero mobility. The unlucky ones must find the hidden antidotes before they weakens and die. Following the rules, solving clues and riddles is an essential factor to their survival.

Leigh Whannell returns as co-writer of the franchise. James Wan(director and co-writer of the original didn't get involve because he's working on a different project)This is definitely one of the best movies of 2005. An instant classic in its genre.I can't decide if this is better or worst than the original but of course, a must see film nonetheless. The acting here is much better than the original. The only one thing I didn't like much is the twist. They obviously didn't want it to end here but the twist, even though surprising, it was just an act of desperation for another sequel. But hey, I'm not complaining much. The movie was worth every penny. The booby traps were ingeniously thought-out. I didn't even bother to buy popcorn or any food while watching it because I knew it was gonna be a bloodbath. Oh yes, there's a lot of blood.

title: a stain on SAW
review:
Oh My God! I loved the first Saw but this was absolute rubbish.

The first film had guile, wit, a psychopathic, sadistic nature about it. I loved the characters, I did not want any harm to come to them. It had me at my wits end throughout the film. Just thinking about the original now I shiver and shake.

The sequel is crap. It's got nothing to do with the original. In fact it got more to do with Cube than anything else. In fact it's more like Cube Part 4 or 5 or whatever it is.

The tragic thing is that the concept of the original was brilliant and it would not have taken a very imaginative mind to make a storming sequel. This one is a stinker.

Mindhunters with Christian Slater is vastly superior to this.

Sorry. I still love the 1st one.

title: A very good sequel!
review: I really enjoyed the first Saw movie and was expecting to be disappointed by a mediocre sequel. I don't know why but the majority of sequels seem cold, rushed and slightly forced. I was however delighted to see that Saw 2 is far better than the original. Although it is a lot more gory than the first one (and this is not a bad thing) this does not detract at all from a stellar performance by the entire cast and a fabulous script. The main characters deliver flawless performances and caused me to be angry, frustrated and devastated or them! The ending of this movie is amazing, although not to me as much of a surprise as it apparently was to other people. Still by no means was I expecting the events to unfurl as they did. At the end of Saw 1 I was left slightly cold as I thought the script deteriorated and became somewhat stale towards the end. Saw 2 remains compelling throughout. I was VERY pleasantly surprised and definitely intend to see it again at the cinema!

title: Oooomg!!!
review: I feel I can't rate this film.. Its too damn difficult. The plot.. I guess.. Was pretty good! And I've realised I did actually like the twist.. And the film.. But it was SO buried under blood and eyeballs it was hard to appreciate. My friend and I sat and squealed, "Noooo!" all the way through. In fact at one point she head butted me in the eye.. Traumatised by the extreme gore? We don't know. It did leave you wanting to see butterflies and "people in the forest in white tunics dancing in slow motion with flowers in their hair". However the more I think about it, the more I realise I did actually enjoy it. So.. Go see it if you don't mind watching people.. Aahh can't tell you that, might get blacklisted. Basically, if you like scary gory films, give it a go! x

title: No. Just no.
review: Okay. This movie was good. Until the end. No, just...no! Ugh why would they do that!? Yeah, expect a sequel and expect to be mad about it. Out of all the horror movies I've seen, this was one of the goriest which made it good. The plot was also really good, but that ending...terrible. I was mad walking out of the theater. They just did not need to do that. It's like watching Freddy Vs. Jason and expecting someone to win, and they both live. Bull crap. Some movies need sequels, some don't. This was one of those movies. If it would have just ended, no sequel teaser, it would have been like a 7 or an 8. An eight! But not now. I'll probably still watch Saw III though.

title: Twists and Turns
review: Saw II's twists and turns will constantly keep you guessing. Trying to follow this movie's constant turns will keep your mind reeling. It pulls you into the movie so far that you can't turn back and keeps you wishing for more. This movie is a must see if you saw the first Saw. Rather gory yes, but still amazing! Definitely not for the people with sensitive stomachs. Jigsaw surprises you again and again with his amazing mind for cruel punishment and his tricks to get people to do exactly what he wants. The game isn't over yet and those unlucky enough to be forced to play will wish they had lived a whole other life. Will you be strong enough to see Jigsaw's revenge on those he believes unworthy of the life they were given?? Let's hope so.

title: Vengeance begets more vengeance. Sometimes it's good to walk away.
review:
As a Christian I always find it funny when people accuse me of legalism, and hypocrisy. For don't we live in a world where everybody expects everybody to do and act the way we want them too? Don't we all at some point ostracize people for being a little off o r out of place? The freaks call the beautiful stuck up, and the beautiful pay no attention to the ugly. We flip off the guy who cuts us off and we hate him because he inconvenienced us for one small moment. We're all guilty of doing somebody wrong, and then when we are wronged we expect the other person to apologize. We want vengeance, and we want the world to think and act just like us. If not we hate them. Trust me we're all guilty at some point, even I am That is just one of the wild thoughts that permeated my mind while sitting through SAW II. Yes, I'll admit it's odd that I would have a somewhat religious epiphany while people are hacking themselves to pieces. But that's the beauty of Horror. It's about processing the horror into something productive, while enjoying the scares.

The Jigsaw Killer (Tobin Bond) is back. This time he's locked a bunch of people in a gory fun-house of his own design. The house is slowly filling with a gas that will kill the inhabitants unless they can find the antidote. One of the Jigsaw Killers victims is the son of Eric Matthews (Donnie Wahlberg), a local cop. Matthews and the local swat team have the Jigsaw Killer in their grasp. What follows is a psychological game that matches the law with a man whose unafraid to die.

SAW II is one of those rare sequels that works because you get to find out more about the psychopath. In this film we get to delve into the mind of the Jigsaw Killer (who goes by the name of John), see a little more about why and how he operates. Tobin Bond keeps him creepy and yet charismatic enough to be believable. Like a poor mans Hannibal Lecter there is a method and meaning to his madness but he's not a cartoon. He's a man on his deathbed with nothing to lose, and a theory of life that is so practical that if he channeled his concepts into motivational speaking and not murder and carnage he could be a millionaire.

I liked that the movie didn't play fast and loose with the carnage and at the same time realized when enough was enough. In this PG-13 Horror movie world it's so easy to pull back to reach a younger audience. But SAW II is smart enough to raise the bar, and let you process the mystery. Whose holding the cards? Is it the Jigsaw Killer? Is it the cops? I also thought the ensemble in the house worked well together, I just wish the screenplay had given them more to do than just stumble around and scream at each other. I also thought the stunning revelation about "X marking the spot" came far to late for the characters to really care about who was in the picture. When your life is almost over you're not really worrying about who put you in jail.

Director Darren Lynn Bousman tries his dandiest not to make the same mistakes of the first film, by laying off the camera tricks in favor actually allowing the actors to act. Sure he wiggles the camera around a little, adds some quick cuts to places. But he doesn't use those devices to amplify action that's boring. My one little qualm was with the screenplay. I liked the stuff in the house so much more than the police procedural parts. I wished that the movie had delved into the whole numbers thing and the mysteries of the people in the house a little more.

SAW II is engrossing if you let it be. On the surface it could be construed as just another slasher knock-off. But the power lies in the Jigsaw character and how and why he's manipulating the background. It's also a film that explores our own dark side. Jigsaw's real beef with the people in the story is that their wasting their lives. Their killing their bodies, they're hurting other, and their tearing their families apart. But the truth lies in the fact that legalism, and your own pursuit to change another persons thinking can also be skewed. So the next time you cut that guy off, or the next time you cut off that guy. Just think to yourself, I've been wronged but should I really wrong back. Vengeance begets more vengeance. Sometimes it's good to walk away.

title: Still can't figure out the ending of Saw 2 ( please help me...)
review:
Hey Guys: I've been reading all the online praises of Saw 2.

I've viewed the film twice and still can't figure out what's going on.

As for the main body of the film, I thought it was weak.

Jigsaw was compelling, but beyond that, everything was formulaic.

Saw (one) had the advantage of introducing the compelling character of Jigsaw along with his methods of killing and torture. How would he kill the next victim and where would they be when they died? What escape would be offered? Suspense was there.

But Saw 2 seems to go back to the same one trick pony.

Opening scene with the "Informer" was great, but also gratuitous and derivative of the first Saw. (Shawnee Smith's head gear..) How many times was a spring loaded door used as a device of suspense? Four times.

How come Amanda and Daniel escape the gas? Not explained.

How does Daniel move from the Saw One dungeon to the safe? Not Explained.

What happened with Addison and the plexiglass cube? What happened to her hands? Never resolved.

What is the purpose of putting Cop Eric in the Dungeon? What lesson is he being taught? Not explained or resolved I just can't figure out how I missed so many loose ends.

I'd really love to have someone tell me what I missed.

I want to be a fan of Saw 2, but for the life of me, I cannot figure out the continuity or ending.

Please, please help me understand this movie Seaview52@yahoo.com

title: Oh Yes, There Was Blood
review:
Very good...at least as good as I expected, if not better.

There was one small continuity error that should have been caught but wasn't.

You'll see it easily enough...

This film does a good job at showing the violent things and at the same time letting your imagination do its thing.

The acting was pretty good -- I mean, I have never been jigsawed or know anyone who has, so I do not know exactly how one would act in those situations.

I am glad, however, that your average serial killer is not that clever.

title: Just a bit of confusion
review: I have yet to see this movie. But, I have read many of these comments and I can't help but to be amazed at how many people loved the first one... Did we See the same movie!? It was riddled by far with the most horrible acting I've seen in a looooooooong time. Now, I am a HUGE fan of horror movies... I'm talking about nerdy nerd movie night watching' mst3k style voice-overing, geek wad who will watch ANYTHING... I'm not trying to say you all don't know what a good movie is but I am still debating on whether or not to watch this one after leaving the first movie laughing at the overacting cheese fest... I mean really pay attention to Danny Glover and you will realize how bad it can get... and the wonderful lines like "if you so much as lay a finger on her"... it was pure cheese. I did like the story though... that was really cool which is why I really need to know if they at least got the dialogue going in sync with the action of it all. I mean no offense to anyone in particular as I am one man posting in a sea of fans... but you have to admit the acting was horrid... at least watch it again with this post in mind and maybe the smoke will clear.

title: Saw 2
review:
Saw 2 was and is the best Thriller/Horror Film this year. It is just as or even better than the first. The suspense, gore, torture, and the twists will blow your mind; this movie will twist and turn you in your seat.

Just the fact of what happens to everyone and the riddles, is just so freak'n cool. Be sure to listen closely to everything and everything that goes on; then ask yourself who is who and what is what. This movie will have you coming back for more.

I myself can not wait till Saw 3 comes out;for fun you could even try solving the riddles yourself. You will be surprised at your answer and the real one.

title: The way a sequel should be
review: When I first heard about the making of this picture I was very concerned because as we all know, sequels are usually never as good as the first, but that's not the case here folks! This film is every bit as good as the first, but in it's own way. This movie "is" a sequel to Saw, and a very good + gory sequel I might add. Still, it doesn't have quite the same feel that the first one had. But don't let that fool you. I can honestly say that this is one of the best sequels that I have ever seen! Like in the first one, the ending of this movie has a huge surprise waiting at the end that will leave you with your mouth left open. For those of you who are reading this that have not yet seen this movie, please take my advice and go see this movie A.S.A.P. I promise you won't regret it.........if you like good movies that is.

title: "Oh Yes, there will be blood"
review: Wow! After this film had finished i ran straight to the bar for a stiff shot of whiskey. 'Saw II' in my eyes was just as Clever, tense and gruesome, with yet another wicked messed up ending, to get your brain twisted again! One to definitely watch if you liked the first 'Saw'. I have to say, coming from myself who gets scared at the very sight of blood, i do find 'Saw 1 & 2 pretty sick and disturbing to the point where i just cant get this film out of my head it sticks with you for about 2 days after. I imagine myself in one of them circumstances and i think 'Heill no!' i don't think so, which is what i think makes these films so intense. Great start and great finish, Excellent film yet again! Enjoy. And remember "There will be Blood".

title: Wow! Now that's scary
review:
I was wondering after the first one how the 2nd movie would be IE single room scenario, couple of actors etc. I love the puzzles created in the first one and I must say they are even better than the first.

It is a LOT more gory than the first one so be prepared this one isn't for the kids but if you liked the first one then you will LOVE this one. From the opening scene you know this one is going to contain a lot more of the same...more puzzles etc though it's strangely more human too as we are more involved with the characters lives than in the first one. As usual the ending is something you never see coming, it will be interesting to see if you can pick it!

title: Man..Oh heavenly man
review:
I just saw this movie. (HAHA no pun intended:P) And I've been left in awe. To the caliber of such great mystery twisters like Seven, this movie holds its own amongst the greats. You know a movie is good, when everyone in the audience, even the cuddling couples, are in complete silence. The twists and turns of this roller coaster film leave you wanting more. If you guessed the ending to this film, congrats. I didn't see it coming. From great camera work, much improved acting from the first saw, bigger budget, better writing, and yes, much more blood, this film will go down as one sequel deserving of a standing ovation. Will there be a Saw 3? If there is, it has a lot to live up to, and if it does, It will be a damn good trilogy to add you a growing collection. So, I leave you with this. If you love blood, if you love edge of your seat suspense, or if you just love getting the crap scared out of you, drop what your doing and go see Saw2! My Star Ratings

Acting 4/5 Stars----Camera Work 4/5 Stars----Plot/Twists 5/5 Stars------ Beginning and Ending 5/5 Stars------- Overall 8.5/10 Stars

title: Another Jigsaw puzzle done right!
review:
Saw II marks Darren Lynn Bousman's debut as a director on a major motion picture (though he directed a couple independent films prior to Saw II), so I was a bit weary as to the quality in the direction of the film. After watching Saw II I realized that Bousman can do it (well).

The film takes place after the events of Saw and the film opens with a bone chilling scene (this definitely prepared the audience for what was to come). Bousman kept to atmosphere of Saw, recreating a dark, dirty, and crazy atmosphere.

The story? I believe the story was well written, though some parts could be questioned as to "if" the characters could get away with what was happening (but then again it's a movie). The ending came to me as a surprise too.

Acting? The acting was good at best (but a few actors of the cast members did a hell of a job). There are moments in the film that had characters acting a bit generic and plain.

Overall, I was very happy with this picture and it is a worthy follow up to the original.

I recommend this tile for sure.

7.5

Thank you, JVL www.jvincentlangel.com

title: A bigger puzzle than before.
review:
Disturbing. Gory. Bloody. And full of a whole lot of "that's got to hurt." Still, like in the previous movie, the clues are all there if you try to pick them out.

We already know from all the reviews that this time around, it's no secret to who Jigsaw is -- even though he himself claims he's not a killer (and ironically, he takes offense to the name "jigsaw").

Still, just as before, Jigsaw gives people tasks. Some bloody and permanently scarring -- some so simple you wonder how people can not do what he asks. And those who don't, well...they wind up gone.

Just the same, we learn more about the background of the illusive "educator", the person who cuts jigsaw pieces out of people to symbolize that they are missing a vital part of what should make them a person. As sick as it is, you find yourself rooting for him.

Sure, he's putting people in horrible situations. Sure, he's a few tacos short of a number three. But the simple cold logic he displays is almost irrefutable.

And then, we have the victims. Stupid, stupid victims. Yes, there is blood, but all the same, I took great delight in watching the squeamish leave the theater (and this film is not for those).

The movie does a nice job in making throwbacks to it's predecessor, with little subscenes that give you just enough of the impression to leave a pleasant aftertaste.

However, I found, that this movie showed a much broader puzzle than the previous, and instead of seeing the whole thing, I felt we were only seeing a couple of the pieces. We don't know all the characters, or how they fit, we don't get intimately involved as we did with the characters in the first. It still kept me glued to the screen.

But still, horrifically bloody (sick, twisted) fun.

title: Dr. Gordon Theory
review:
I just took in a second showing of Saw 2 and formulated my theory for how all this crazy business will wrap up. Now stay with me on this...

In the opening "death mask" kill of Saw 2, Jigsaw directs Michael's attention to a video of his eye operation. Notice two things about this scene: 1.) Obviously the point of the movie is to enjoy it and not nit-pick every little detail that seems unrealistic. I'll give Jigsaw the benefit of the doubt for building his traps, but to implant a key behind someone's eye socket so they can still see takes MEDICAL KNOWLEDGE.

2.) The cloaked man operating on Michael is limping! I didn't believe it when a friend pointed it out to me, so i took careful watch the second time around. Is he limping on the same leg that Dr. Gordon chopped off? Obviously this theory means you need to suspend a lot of disbelief, but that's the flavor of the Saw movies. Plus, they take careful consideration to show Zepp and Adam's bodies, but only Dr. Gordon's foot. Think about it...

title: See Saw 2 (but see Saw too before you see Saw 2)
review:
This Halloween see Saw 2 but see Saw before you see Saw 2 to understand what you saw. Not see-saw, but see Saw before you see Saw 2. If you saw Saw too, you must see Saw 2 to see the conclusion of what you saw. If you already saw Saw 2, then go see Saw too to make sense of Saw 2. So when you're out next to see a movie, see Saw 2 Â– not see-saw 2 but see Saw 2, but not before you see Saw.

What I saw in Saw 2 was different to when I saw Saw. Although we see Jigsaw who we see in Saw too return to Saw 2, what we see is a psychotic sequel superior to Saw and scarier too. If you loved seeing Saw, you would love to see the Saw sequel: Saw 2

title: Not Frightful as the first, but still the same thrills.
review: After scaring myself half to death with the original SAW, I almost cried when I heard that they were going to bring out a sequel which wasn't going to hold a candle to the original. When the film finally came out I decided to see for myself how terrible this was going to be. The acting was alright, not adrenaline rushing like the last one but pretty decent and the scenes that were supposed to make the audience scream with fright were just dead and cheap. I was waiting for that one scene that was going to make me scream and throw my popcorn up in the air like the last one, but no. There was no scene like that, just a bunch of scenes that were trying to be scary like a Sci-Fi Channel original movie. The film did as I predicted, it did leave me disappointed but I was impressed with the work they put into the script. It may not be a walk through the carnival spook house but it did have the twists and turns of that roller coaster that looks like it is touching the sky. I would only suggest this movie to people who saw the first SAW but only after the movie has been in theaters two weeks so they could use their free pass tickets.

title: Yes there was blood.
review: This was just as good as the first movie. I liked Wahlberg. He was great. The cast was decent. There was blood but it was that fake looking blood. Hold on to your seats for the end. It was good. You have to see the first one to understand this one. If you do not remember the first one, just rent it before you see SAW 2. I loved the opening scene; pretty gross in that movie gory kinda way. This movie goes to show how brilliant and nuts a filmmaker's mind can be!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! YES THERE WILL BE BLOOD. A LOT OF IT. If you like blood, suspense, and sick, twisted Hollywood, then this movie is for you.

title: Mindscape? Boycott? No way....
review: I had to start a new thread since the boycott one got so off track. I just got back from the theater. This was an excellent movie, and I feel will truly be one people either love or hate. The story was great, I especially liked the entire purpose of why everyone was in the house. I can't understand why any horror fan would not see this flick. But I can in a way see why people would not consider this a horror movie; to boycott it though, absolutely not. This is, love it or hate it, the new genre in horror. Mindscape wants to boycott it because it isn't in his opinion, horror . It is and you my friend showed your hand too early. You like the 30's horrors and up to mentioning Argento and Barker. I think I remember people saying Hellraise should be boycotted too. The films of the 30's provided scares for fans because it was new to them. History moves on and things progress. People need a new type of scare and the guy in the closet isn't doing it anymore. This is where guys like Bousman, Takashi Mike, and Rob Zombie come in. They aren't the garden variety directors and writers anymore. There are great plot lines, stunning filming techniques, and bright, new angles and ideas in camera-work (Thank you Mark Romanek for that Nine Inch Nails Video). This is what I like to call "gore thrillers" and God I hope they don't go away.

title: A top notch sequel
review: This is the way that sequels SHOULD be! It is set-up a bit differently than the first film. It begins with Donnie Wahlberg's character trying to track down Jigsaw and the story progresses fom there. Later on in the film, we are introduced to a house full of people all strangers to each other and set up to survive Jigsaw's master plot. Great story, acting (Donnie Wahlberg really does well in this) and violence. It has surprises just like the original, and if you liked the first film, you need to see this one. Very rerely does a sequel come along that holds the payoff of the original, however this film delivers all the surprises of the original.

title: I like to See Saw 2
review:
This is a very scary movie, feels and looks the same as the original, only letdown is the standard of acting from the victims especially the Black guy and the Hispanic guy and character development is zero but thats OK, its not gonna be up for any Oscars or anything and I was pleasantly surprised by Donnie Whalberg.

Go see this if you like gory claustrophobic horrors, they don't come much better, with a slight mix of horror genres for good measure, it has elements of haunted house movies mixed with psychological thriller, slasher and just good old fashioned plain horror for the sake of it.

Although I really enjoyed the movie I do hope they don't make anymore, as good as it is, you can just see a whole host of sequels and prequels and god knows what else popping up over the next few years that would only detract from two of the best horror movies made since the seventies, fingers crossed.

title: love it but predictable..here's why
review: I loved SAW with a passion. The end of the first one blew my mind. Was so into it that i watch it several times that i analyzed every detail which is possibly y i predicted the ending. Not a bad one at all just predictable to those who really pay attention to the first one. Here's why: In Saw 1 the girl who survived ACTUALLY survived and stated " HE SAVED ME!!!" Therefore appreciated what he had done to her because he had thus saved her from continuing to be a drug addict. So WHY would she be dumb enough to do it again and be back in the game. Only thought that came across my mind was that she appreciated him so much for what he's done, what better way to thank him than to help him have other people see why life is so fragile and important. But again was a good ending, just SAW 1 was completely out of left field and had u thinking that everyone was the possible killer up until the VERY end. What WAS intelligent was Jigsaw's rule concerning to just sit there and talk to him and he will see his son. That i did not see coming. Also booby trap ideas...VERY creative. That's what I enjoy most about the SAW movies in general. Plus Saw ! did not need all the blood to capture your attention. SAW 1 10/10 SAW 2 8/10

title: Lacks the ingenuity of the first, but still entertaining
review:
For those who "saw" and liked the first SAW, you will no doubt be entertained by the sequel. "The Jigsaw Killer" is back, with more dastardly, sadistic traps for his slacker victims.

This time, John is caught by the police right at the beginning of the movie. As usual, however, John has anticipated his capture and reveals video screens that depict his latest victims (one of whom is the son of one of the lead police detectives), trapped in a house filled with his deadly devices. John poses a simple test to the police detective: sit here and talk to me and I'll return your son, safe and sound. The problem for the detective is how to do that when the video screens vividly portray the suffering and death of John's latest victims.

SAW II lacks the shock value of the original because the gimmick is familiar to fans of the first movie. There are more victims in this movie, but unfortunately, the number of victims dilutes the suspense because we the audience do not get the opportunity to learn as much about them as we did the victims in the original. The victims in this film are little more than cannon fodder for John and, as such, we care very little for their ultimate fate. Worse still, the deaths of some of the victims (particularly Beverly Mitchell of "Seventh Heaven" fame) are, it pains me to say, boring, especially given what we've come to anticipate from the more ingenious death traps shown in the first movie.

Once again, even the "heroes" of the film aren't people one especially wants to root for, but again, the leads are so thinly drawn that the horror of their ultimate fate eludes us. It's one thing when the innocent are tortured, but when the guilty are punished, however horribly, it's hard to get too worked up about it.

The "twist" ending wasn't much of a twist, especially compared to the first movie and smacks of deriving too much from many a bad slasher sequel. The police detective's son's final fate was a bit less predictable, but ultimately unsatisfying, given that his father's fate seemed to violate the rules of the "Game."

In any event, the first movie was a far superior film, but this one still had enough shocks and thrills to make it worth a trip to the theater. For fans of the original, however, it will be somewhat of a letdown.

title: Left 30 mins till end
review: Me and my boyfriend went a saw Saw 2 the day it came out. We loved the first one so much we thought the second one would be awesome. We loved it but had to leave cause he got sick. We had to leave the movie theater and call 911 for him and I didn't get to see the end of it. He's fine, just got food poison and now we have no idea what happened in the movie and its killing us. So would someone please tell me what happens. We left at the part when Xavier started killing people for the safe numbers. He was chasing after the boy and girl and that's all I know.The dad (cop, Donnie Wahlburg) was threatening JigSaw to take him to the place. Thanks!

title: Best Scary Movie in a Long Time
review: This is the best scary movie that i have seen in a long time by far........ IT is as good if not better than the first one. The plot outline of this movie follows the first one by having a game type theme but it is a movie that will keep you in your seat with your eyes glued to the screen the characters are jigsaw a policeman and 5 people that are trapped in a room and are being forced to play jigsaws cynical game. you will want a sequel believe me. especially with one of the best twists at the end of the movie which will have you on the edge of your seat! I gave it a 10/10 o and another thing you wouldn't want to buy popcorn for this movie because you'll be watching the movie the whole time and wont have time to eat it

title: I'm Glad I SAW This Too
review:
I will begin this review by saying that I absolutely enjoyed Saw part one. I was surprised that it would be so different than the average horror/gore flick. I believe that it is the best movie of its kind in a long time. Now here is the sequel. If you know nothing of the first Saw or did not understand it, you will be confused, perhaps lost, and find this movie bizarre and maybe even dumb. But it is as genius as the first one. When the movie starts, we already know that we are in for something different than the first. It has a distinct feel and seems like a typical horror movie at the beginning. But as it goes along, the Saw feel returns and the tension begins. I cannot describe any more about the movie here without spoiling anything. The Jigsaw killer is awesome, his games are sick and twisted, and this movie is excellent. Forget what the critics say. I have come to realize that they cannot appreciate a movie like this for what it is. Look at their reviews for this and you will see what I mean. I mainly take into consideration how the screenwriter is a new guy (only other movie is Saw one) and he managed to come together with two first-time directors and produce a very different and interesting movie. Many experienced writers/directors cannot even do that. As the Jigsaw killer says: yes, there is blood here, and a lot of it. If you could not handle the first Saw, I do not know how your tolerance level will be here. There are a lot of moments of disgust. But if you enjoyed the first Saw, you will either find this too weird or outstanding. There is a lot of information about Jigsaw that gives us more of an understanding of who he is and how twisted his mind is. There are so many instances in which we even want to agree with him. I find that to be good writing on a character's part, and surprising to most, there are a lot of symbolic images here that involve the clock and the jigsaw piece that the killer takes from his subjects' skin. I'm glad I SAW this too along with the first one. It certainly lives up its predecessor (and most sequels do not), and I was afraid it would not. Go see this for yourself, especially if you liked the twistedness of the first Saw =)

8.2/10 Stars

title: Intense. Just intense.
review:
WOW. I've been a horror movie fanatic since I was a little kid, my parents were buying me movies like "Halloween" and "The Shining" for Christmas and birthdays when I was 8 years old. I'm not squeamish, and no horror movie scares me.

When I saw Saw last year I was blown away, It was the creepiest, goriest, most twisted horror movie ever... I bought it immediately the day it was released on DVD. Finally, a horror movie for my generation! It quickly because one of my favorites, the plot, the directing, the sheer gruesomeness that actually made me cringe..

My boyfriend and I went to Saw 2 on Friday, opening night, I was expecting an OKAY sequel.. it was mind blowing.

The movie was so intense, I because very nauseated in the first few minutes and we considered leaving. After the movie was over, I actually had a Panic Attack and my bf and I sat in the movie theater parking lot for 2 hours while I tried to calm down.

Excellent movie. Any movie that can freak me out at all, especially to that degree... just wow.

title: Decent film, but failed to match it's predecessor
review: I went to see this film last night in a cinema with only about 20 people in it and you could have heard a pin drop. It's always good to be able to see a film with like minded individuals who don't go to the cinema to catch up on gossip. You would like to think that anyone going to see this film would know exactly what they were in for, which in this case seemed to keep out those hoping to see some mildly scary 'boo!' shocker that we have seen before. Anyway, I digress. As a stand alone movie, this would have been far more effective for me. But, unfortunately, for someone who was trying really hard to enjoy it as much as I had 'Saw', it let me down in several departments. I guess a lot of that may have to do with the setting. Some of the atmosphere is inevitably lost in a cinema. In your front room with the lights down and creaky boiler, who knows, things may have been different. But from the start of this, the foreboding unknown quantity that heralded the first one was absent. Yes the Venus fly trap contraption was horrible and the dilemma was,er, unfortunate for the guy but I never really felt that shocked. That for me was about as evil as it got and the predicaments that others in the movie found themselves in never quite matched the initial one, nasty as they certainly were. I felt that there were so many other ideas that could have been used and that would have increased the cringe factor. I didn't cringe once! When you consider some of the devices of torture and death used throughout the centuries, is falling into a pit of needles really that bad! The acting was OK and was at an acceptable level, considering the material. It didn't need to be great because that's not what we come for, but all involved did fine for what was required which was to look and act scared / shocked / angry etc at the right time. The story has pretty much been discussed to death (ho ho geddit!) so everyone should know it by now. The story, however, is not as good as in the first 'Saw', and to my mind was never going to be. The environment was not as creepy and intimidating and there were more characters involved. The first 'Saw' was much more personal and intimate and you felt that you were in the same room to a certain extent. In the sequel, I felt that I was watching it more from a distance and did not feel as involved. To achieve the feelings of fear / anxiety / dread that all horror movies strive for (don't they?) you have to feel a certain amount of sympathy / empathy with at least one of the characters and build around them an atmosphere where you know and feel evil things can happen. In 'Saw 2', gory as it was, there was no real dread, just waiting for the next set-piece, which, if more elaborate and interesting, would have saved the film, but they weren't. I enjoyed the film and didn't expect it to live up to the original. I wouldn't advise seeing it before the first film as it will spoil it, but it is unfortunate that some of what made the first so interesting is missing this time. As an aside, as a 35 year old, I still can't get used to seeing Donnie Wahlberg as a Dad!

title: It'll do.
review:
Last year I watched SAW for the first time and I didn't know anything about it, I just heard it's something with two guys stuck in a room. So, in that aspect, the first SAW handed me a plate of surprises, this one on the otherhand was just a Halloween night filler for me and my wife.

The plot was more heavily elaborated on and we get to meet and know Jigsaw, which in itself was much needed I suppose, without that you just have a pretty mindless viewing of a booby-trapped house that people fall prey to with no real 'movie'. (see "Cube") All in all, if you're a horror/thriller connoisseur with your roots planted in the likes of 'Halloween', 'Black Christmas' and 'the Shining', this film may be tolerable enough to be a "B-side" track on an album you really like, but not one that stands out. However if you get your charge with a straight on gore-fest, and can sit there and eat a plate of Padgett with ease while watching someone's brains get smashed and slurped up, this is a cant miss.

title: Am I watching Saw again??
review:
As weak, Unsurprising, ungory and unshocking as the first film.

Dreadful acting (again) terrible music and editing (again). And what the hell is it with those damn car scenes?? It looks more suited to a comedy scene!

Was i meant to be sitting there saying WOW to the usual suspects-esk flashbacks and twist at the end?? Just did not do nothing for me at all. The only real plus point of the film was Tobin Bell, who was excellent throughout.

I came out of the cinema thinking 'Is that it'?? Just like the first film. If you have seen Saw don't see Saw 2. It is the same film!

My opinion in a nutshell:

Se7en: The Idiots Version.

title: Fun and bloody, but nowhere near the quality of the first.
review:
"Could contain Spoilers"

Saw 2 opens with yet another doomed victim who lacks an appreciation for life - not a good character trait to have when the Jigsaw killer is hungry for gaming. In this most anticipated sequel, the first victim wakes in a grungy room wearing only an iron contraption around his neck and a pair of navy blue boxer briefs. Soon enough, a nearby TV turns on to reveal that creepy papier-mâché mask that we all have come to know and love. Through a brief explanation, we learn that some hours earlier, Mr. Joe Boxer had a key implanted behind his eyeball; the evidence of which is shown on the TV in an x-ray. The key unlocks the "Death Mask", a spring loaded spiked device, that he has woken up wearing. Armed only with a scalpel and a mirror, he must cut the key out of his head and unlock the mask before it snaps shut and kills him. To make matters worse, he only has 60 seconds to do it! Talk about a rude awakening! He's just woken up and he has a split second to decide if he would rather lose an eye or die When I first wake up, it takes me 3 minutes just to remember what day it is Rough day for this guy The TV turns off abruptly the game has begun. Does he perform this gruesome surgical procedure? Better yet, does he perform it within the given time? Seeing how this is the opening of the film, you should be guessing no. Bingo SMASH! The mask closes like a Venus flytrap on steroids.

Enter hero Donnie Wahlberg playing the role of Detective Eric Matthew. He walks onto the crime scene and after five minutes basically says, "I'm outta here!" What? Wait a minute are you sure? Maybe you want to find a clue before you leave? Eventually, he decides to look a little closer, which leads to the discovery of a manufacturer's label on the death mask. Calling all cars! Everyone heads down to the manufacturing plant where they discover The Jigsaw Killer. "Gotcha", says Detective Matthew. Yep, he's a smart one all right. Jigsaw tells Matthew to look in the other room. He sees a group of monitors displaying eight victims in an isolated, grunge infested room. To really hit home, Matthew sees that one of the victims is his teenage son. Let the games begin Detective.

Here's how the game is played folks  The eight victims are trapped inside a house. There is a toxic nerve agent in the house that is seeping into their bodies. The door to the house will open in three hours but within two, their bodies will bleed from every internal organ. Throughout the house are games that, if won, will yield an antidote, but usually just a single dose. This leads to one of my first major problems with the film. OK, you have a decent size house to explore and only two hours to do so. The first thing I would do is form some kind of a plan, look around the room very carefully for clues, etc What do these guys choose to do first? Freak out. Fine, we'll give them a few minutes to do that. However, I felt like they never stopped arguing. I understand that these eight personalities vary to the extreme but it was very annoying to see the clock ticking while they do absolutely nothing to benefit themselves. You have one girl on the ground crying half the time and another one telling everyone to shut up. Towards the finale, one of these characters becomes an even bigger threat to the household than Jigsaw very odd story choice in my opinion.

As you might have guessed, I really would have liked to see the characters working together more, or better yet, working together at all. I felt the script should have spent more time playing with what the characters knew and didn't know, as in the first film. You had two characters chained up in a bathroom. One of them would secretly read a note hidden by Jigsaw and instantly we know that Adam knows something Lawrence doesn't. Then five minutes later Lawrence reads a note.
